title: Brexit news UK EU Dominic Raab Ireland border backstop Simon Coveney Michel Barnier latest
story: Brexit news: Dominic Raab receives EU rejection for temporary Irish backstop proposals (Image: )Ireland&rsquos deputy prime minister Simon Coveney issued a public rebuke to the Brexit Secretary after the UK cabinet member demanded the right to pull Britain out backstop arrangement after three months.Mr Raab left Irish officials &ldquostunned last week when he said Britain should be free to quit the Irish backstop after just three months because the UK risks being trapped in a &ldquolimbo of indefinite customs union membership.But Mr Coveney has once again sent British negotiators back to the drawing board, telling them a &ldquotime-limited backstop will be rejected by Brussels.Writing on Twitter, he said: &ldquoThe Irish position remains consistent and very clear that a &lsquotime-limited backstop&rsquo or a backstop that could be ended by the UK unilaterally would never be agreed by Ireland or the EU.&ldquoThese ideas are not backstops at all and don&rsquot deliver on previous UK commitments.Sabine Weyand, EU negotiator Michel Barnier&rsquos deputy, reposted the message to her own followers on the social media platform in a snub to Mr Raab&rsquos perceived plan.She added: &ldquoStill necessary to repeat this, it seems.The Irish border still remains the most contentious issues in the Brexit negotiations as both sides battle for an acceptable backstop, the mechanism designed to prevent a hardening of the Irish border under a permanent solution is found.                Brexit news: France warns it faces 'PARALYSIS' if no deal is agreedBrussels has opened up to a possible compromise to its own plans, which would essentially keep Northern Ireland in its customs union and single market for goods, after protests from Theresa May.The Prime Minister agreed to the concept of a backstop being legally included in the Brexit withdrawal agreement but opposes the EU&rsquos current position.She said &ldquono prime minister would be able to accept the EU offer because it questions the constitutional structure of the UK.EU officials are said to be preparing to consider a UK-wide customs union or an extension of the 21-month transition period but are still waiting on Britain to table an official offer.But senior diplomats have told Express that lengthening the transition period isn&rsquot an answer to the vexed backstop issue and only serves as potential insurance policy against the mechanism being triggered in the future.Last week, Mr Coveney told British negotiators they would have to table any new offers this week if they want to conclude a deal the end of November.This week is seen as the unofficial deadline for progress if EU leaders are to bring back shelved plans for an emergency summit.Irish prime minister Leo Varadkar has signalled he would like to see the Brexit deal completed by the end of 2018 if it cannot be concluded in November.

title: Brexit news UK EU Ireland ferry duty free sale Dublin Holyhead travel latest
story: Brexit news: Ireland ferry firm planing for duty-free shopping return on UK routes (Image: )International Continental Group has made space on its new passenger ferry the WB Yeats to smooth the way for possible post-Brexit duty-free shopping.The firm, whose &pound126 million ship will operate between Dublin and Holyhead, has made the changes as a contingency for relaxed rules.The European Union put an end to duty-free shopping for those travelling between member states in 1999.Despite desperate lobbying, Brussels stood firm and prevented its return, but after Brexit that may change.Low-cost alcohol, cigarettes and perfume could be sold to passengers travelling between EU countries and the UK depending on the terms of the withdrawal agreement.Firms do not yet know if duty-free will be able to return after the UK&rsquos formal exit day on March 29, 2029, or after the proposed transition period in December 2020.Despite the uncertainty, ICG made the alterations their new ferry after the WB Yeats was delivered late by its German shipbuilder.&nbspFlensburger Schiffbau-Gesselschaft blamed its own suppliers for the delays after the firm only delivered the ferry last month.                Brexit news: France warns it faces 'PARALYSIS' if no deal is agreedBut ICG took advantage of the displays and insisted on the &ldquocontingency plans for a potential return of duty-free.Irish ferry firms would receive a significant financial boost from the return of duty-free because most of their business operates between Ireland and the UK.DAA, the state company that operates Cork and Dublin airports, has described the potential return of duty-free as one of the few Brexit victories for Ireland.Kevin Toland, its former chief executive, last year told Irish politicians low-cost shopping would benefit the country&rsquos airports.Ireland should position itself as the &lsquobusiness destination of choice&rsquo, he said.&nbspBut Mr Toland also said Brexit would result in fewer flights between Ireland and Britain.He warned the need to prioritise the airline industry in Ireland, advising that, out of the EU-27 members, Ireland is most dependant on the UK, with traffic to and from the UK representing 36 percent of Dublin Airport&rsquos business.Despite Ireland&rsquos reliance on Britain for business, the country&rsquos prime minister Leo Varadkar says Brexit has put a strain on their relationship.Last week, he said: &ldquoAnything that pulls the communities apart in Northern Ireland undermines the Good Friday Agreement, and anything that pulls Britain and Ireland apart undermines that relationship.

story: A flag flutters on New Caledonia, little knowing the storm that was about to be released (Image: Theo RoubyAFP)While heavily dependent on state handouts, the Pacific islands of New Caledonia percent of voters said &ldquono, while 43.3 percent said &ldquoyes.&nbspBut the unexpectedly tight result shows that separatists have expanded their influence, and could demand greater autonomy from the mainland despite the &ldquono vote.&nbsp&nbspA &ldquoyes vote would have deprived Paris of a foothold in the Indo-Pacific region where China is gaining ground, and dented the pride of France, a former colonial power whose reach once ned the Caribbean, sub-Saharan Africa and the Pacific Ocean.&nbspMany also feared the referendum would re-ignite tensions between the Kanak people and the white population, which has settled since France annexed the islands in 1853.                Earthquake today: New Caledonia hit by HUGE 6.3 quake and 16 tremorsMore than 1,000 gendarmes were deployed to the streets to maintain order, and the carrying of firearms and the sale of alcohol were banned during the weekend.However few violent incidents were reported. Several cars &ndash seven, according to police sources &ndash were torched in the hours following the announcement of the result.&nbspMr Macron said he understood the disappointment of those who had voted in favour of independence, but added that the French state would ensure &ldquoliberty, equality and fraternity for everyone.&nbsp&ldquoThe only loser is the temptation of contempt, ision, violence and fear the only winner is the process of peace and the spirit of dialogue, the 40-year-old leader said.&nbsp&nbspLocated some 18,000 kilometres from the French mainland, New Caledonia is home to a quarter of the world&rsquos known supplies of nickel &ndash a vital electronics component.&nbspDespite this, islanders are heavily dependent on state handouts &ndash&nbsp &pound1.14bn (&euro1.3 billion) a year &ndash especially the native Kanak community, which is plagued by high school dropout rates, chronic unemployment and poor housing conditions.These differences caused ethnic tensions in the 1980s which claimed more than 70 lives.This led to the 1998 Noumea Accord which paved the way for a steady devolution of powers as well as Sunday's referendum.

title: i sold my sperm for quick cash when i was skint now ive got 24 kids meet the 57 year old sperm donor who believes he could have hundreds of children
story: Nor could he have possibly imagined she would go on to tell him he had fathered dozens more children over the past three decades - after he worked as a £-a-go sperm donor to get some extra cash in his twenties. Now, almost three decades later, orced and childless, Peter, , has been contacted by  children aged  to  who discovered he was their dad using DNA testing and then tracked him down online - and he believes there could be hundreds more.The extended donor family - which also includes three grandchildren - now try to hang out several times a month - meeting up for dinner, bowling and even going on family holidays.And the number keeps growing - with a new kid getting in contact with Peter every month.It was a shock at first, but now when I look around at all these kids I feel giddy, he told Sun Online.I cant believe I was a part - even a small part - of creating all these wonderful kids.I dont know for sure how many kids there might be - the sperm bank doesn’t have complete records.Peters situation raises worrying ethical concerns about donors in the States.While in the UK donors can only legally father  children, across the pond there are no limits and regulations.This is something some of Peters donor kids are concerned about.Sun Online joined Peter and seven of his kids on a family outing in Los Angeles, where they played an Escape Room game and went for a vegan Italian meal.Peter and the children have a designated Facebook group and spreadsheet to help them keep in touch and plan meet-ups.Many of the kids have similar physical or personality traits, and bizarrely they all seem to get on like they’ve known each other for years - even though some of them have only met in the past month.Theatre director Peters donor children live all over the US and the world - including France and China.Theyve not managed to get all  together at the same time but hope to one day.Sidney, is the youngest of the siblings at  and had no idea who his donor father was until he took a DNA test on the website andme, which matches people with their genetic relatives.“I have two moms so I always knew I had a donor father but he was completely anonymous,” Sidney explained.“Then I took the test and got connected with my sister Rachel and brother Peter and we kept growing.“It’s weird to say that you have become friends with your siblings because usually you grow up with them, but in the past year that’s what’s happened to me.“It’s great for me because I’m an only child so I haven’t grown up with brothers or sisters so it’s nice now to get to go out and hang out with my siblings.“It’s funny when I tell people that I have  siblings because they don’t believe me - they think I’m lying.”Peter’s donor daughter Rachel was the first one to reach out to Peter.She had already managed to locate  of her donor siblings using the donor register and andme.Pooling together dferent information they had been given from their parents, they figured out that their dad was an actor from Los Angeles and they knew his name.She put the name into a movie database and found a “Peter Ellenstein”, then managed to track him down on Facebook.Musician Rachel, , said she was most interested in seeing a picture of her biological father and learning a little bit more about “where she came from and how she got here”.Rachel and Peter hit it off and became very close - now they speak to each other most days and even enjoyed a holiday to France together, where they visited another donor sibling.Peter described meeting Rachel for the first time - via video chat - as “dferent than anything Id ever felt before.”He said: “It was a profound feeling looking at someone who so clearly resembled me and some of my mannerisms and it turned out we had all kinds of things in common.“We actually met the next day in person and we hugged for a long time and cried and talked.Rachel told him she had made contact with  other siblings and over the course of the year Peter began meeting them.Another  kids then came forward over the next year - with the most recent two coming forward just three weeks ago.Peter said his friends and family have all reacted dferently to the news of his new family - but his -year-old mother is delighted to suddenly have so many grandchildren.“The reactions of everybody have been all over the map,” he said.My mother is thrilled she says, the more, the merrier’.Peter, who donated sperm for about six years - sometimes as often as five times a week -says he tries to let each of his children decideand how they want to meet - and they also decide what they want to call him.Some call him “DNA dad”, “donor father”, “lab dad” or just plain old Peter. Others refer to him as father or dad.Alana, , who has a twin sister Bridget, said she was more interested in meeting other siblings - than gaining a new dad - but is glad that she has met Peter.“We were raised by a mother and a father so we already had that father figure,” she said.“For us we wanted to know about our other siblings and find outwe had anything in common with them, were there were any similarities  Do we look like each other “My mother told me when I was  that we had a donor father and I was always curious but it wasn’t until  that we tracked down any siblings.”And although Alana and Bridget are “super excited” about suddenly acquiring so many siblings - they do think there should be more regulation on how many children can be created from one man’s sperm.“I think there should be a cap - we are probably going to be hitting  soon in the next year - it’s a lot,” she said.“There’s so many of us that live in Calornia too - whatwe fell in love with someone and they turned out to be a sibling  That would be terrible.“Some of the siblings have already figured out that they knew each other from before - from being in the same classes - but they didn’t know they had the same donor dad.“I sometimes wonder when I’m looking at people walking down the street or on the bus - whatthat’s my sibling Peter says he says he is careful not to try and replace anybody’s actual parents.Most of the real parents have been supportive - some have felt a little concerned but theyve soon come around when theyve seen the benefits for their kids having so many siblings, Peter explained.“I feel like I get to be a part of  dferent adventures.“I didnt have any children of my own. I had a step daughter with my ex we but Id never raised my own kids.“And when I first saw Rachel, part of my brain and a part of my heart opened up that I didnt know that I had before. And I cant really explain what it is.“It was a mixture of sort of a sense of longevity, of purpose, wonder. Im really just feeling things that Id never experienced before.”Peter and his donor kids are now eagerly waiting to seemore of his children come forward.And its clear thatthey do, they will be welcomed into the unique donor family with open arms. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: His Home Office seems more dysal now even than when a large chunk of it was condemned as “not fit for purpose”  years ago.His junior minister and civil servants seem clueless about their own post-Brexit immigration policy.His predecessor Amber Rudd was given such woeful advice by two ­bungling senior officials she had to resign after repeating it.Mr Javid himself is having to be warned against the disastrous error of expanding “hate crime” to include ageism and misogyny.Britain is being engulfed by a tsunami of violence. title: corbyn ally councils buy homes
story: Corbynista Lloyd Russell-Moyle believes town hall chiefs should be given power of first refusal on any house up for sale.And he wants to tear up planning laws to allow them to build high-rise flats in posh suburbs and leafy villages.Mr Russell-Moyle, , revealed his party will order mass compulsory purchases of former council homes sold off under the Tories’ Right To Buy scheme.But he told a Labour rally: “Let’s not just talk about council houses — let’s get those bloody private houses back into our hands.”The Brighton Kemptown MP — an ally of Jeremy Corbyn — is urging the Labour leader to take swathes of privately-owned property into public control.Left-wing activists cheered as he unveiled his plan at an anti-austerity conference under the banner “Stand With Corbyn”.Mr Russell-Moyle said a future Labour government would abolish the right to buy and “compulsory purchase en masse” sold-off housing stock.He told the London rally: “We need to develop a system that slowly over time takes property out of private hands and puts it into public hands.“For example, why not give every council the first right of refusal with any houses put up for sale “And I don’t mean a former council house — I mean your private house.”A Tory MP last night called it “pure madness”.Ex-housing minister Grant Shapps said: “The truth’s out — cuddly Corbyn wants to nationalise your home.”If voters needed any reminding of the Marxist-inspired madness that would descend after a Corbyn victory, Brighton MP Lloyd Russell-Moyle has provided it.The ‘right to buy’ revolution, letting people buy their council houses, was the bedrock of Margaret Thatcher’s premiership.It enabled millions to gain a stake in society which they could then pass on to their children.But under the powers to compulsorily purchase ex council houses, he also wants to see them get first refusal on any private homes that come on the market.Although not official Labour policy, the MP was cheered to title: foreign investors brexit liam fox opinion
story: People want to buy our world-class British products and companies want to use our services.And investors want to put their money into the UK because, like us, they know that they are investing in a country that is set to prosper as we leave the EU.New figures from the internationally respected organisation UNCTADshowed that during the first six months of , only China secured more inward investment into their country than the UK.According to the UN, China secured billion, the UK .billion and the US .billion. The Netherlands and Spain were the only other EU countries in the top ten.That is some achievement for the UK. And demonstrates that the people who know where to invest, know it should be in the UK.They know we live in a dynamic nation, brimming with potential.So as we leave the European Union, we should remember the many reasons investors choose to put their money here in the United Kingdom, which is one of the world’s largest and most successful economies.We are at record levels of employment. Our success is underpinned by a legal system whose reputation is second to none. We have a skilled workforce and a low tax and a well-regulated economy.We are home to some of the finest universities, our research and development capabilities are cutting-edge and our financial institutions world-leading.We are in the right time zone to trade with Asia in the morning and the United States in the afternoon — and, of course, we speak English, the language of global business.Plus, there is serious global momentum behind businesses in the UK. We continue to attract more Foreign Direct Investmentthan anywhere  in Europe. And we are the number one choice in Europe for key strategic investments, such as headquarters. So it’s easy to see why more than , new businesses start up here every day.And it isn’t just small and medium-sized businesses. The UK has created  of Europe’s  companies valued at more than billion.Only this week Monzo, the British bank which operates through an app on your phone, secured £million of investment in order to double its workforce. This raised the company’s value to the £billion mark just three years after its formation.This is a fantastic vote of confidence in the UK and yet another sign that we have plenty to be optimistic about after we leave the EU.Investment creates jobs across all parts of the UK, pumps money into our communities and improves the lives of millions of people.Last year, FDI created , new jobs in the UK as well as safeguarding another ,.One reason we are seeing so much success is that this government has built an environment that makes investment and job creation easy.We are champions of free trade and we actively encourage businesses of all sizes — from start-ups to large corporations — to build trading links in all corners of the world.This weekend I’ll be representing the UK at the China International Import Expo in Shanghai where we are a “country of honour”.Over recent months, China has started to open up its market for UK goods and services, including dairy products, potatoes and petrol stations.And, this weekend, we intend to build on these achievements and create even more exciting opportunities for British companies.We also possess world-class talent. For example, we excel at research and development, which means that overseas companies want to tap into British expertise to advance the quality of their products. In last week’s Budget, we announced a further £.billion to strengthen the UK’s global leadership in science and innovation — that brings the total to £billion invested in research and development since .We want a partnership with business to make our country prosper.The Government’s Industrial Strategy includes innovative deals agreed with inidual sectors to attract investment. We are already reaping the rewards.The global marketplace never slows and we, too, must never stand still.Building on our impressive investment success, I have implemented the High Potential Opportunities scheme, which will deliver growth where it is most needed, often to previously overlooked areas.The success of the AgriTech programme in the West Midlands town of Telford and Leicestershire’s leading space sector cluster are proof the benefits of global investment are being felt in every part of the country.Over recent months, the Department for International Trade has led a series of investment roundtables, promoting UK industry to a global audience and driving foreign direct-investment into the UK as we prepare to leave the European Union.So far, these events have centred on tech, le sciences, automotive and agri-tech sectors and will soon start to focus on areas such as the creative industries.Initiatives such as this are going to be key in the coming months as we develop the UK’s own independent trade policy for the first time in more than  years.Working with businesses in the UK and overseas, I am determined to continue generating this flow of good news.But the facts tell a dferent story: Confidence in Britain is riding so high around the world that foreign investors are betting on it like never before.New UN figures show that in the first six months of  we were second only to booming China in attracting investment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: james brokenshire communities open doors project
story: As Communities Secretary, I am committed to creating strong, well-integrated communities and to bringing people together in common spaces to celebrate the great places we live and work.High streets can and do play a big part in this vision. We want to see vibrant hubs where people live, shop, use services, and come together.I recognise that these challenges are linked. Empty shops and decreasing footfall on the high street can contribute to social problems such as crime, unemployment and loneliness, while successful high streets can make communities stronger.That is why this week I am launching the new Open Doors project to help regenerate the high street and support community groups.The scheme will match landlords of vacant commercial units with community groups offering vital services to younger and older people. The aim is to reduce loneliness among our most vulnerable members of the community, whilst increasing footfall in town centres.We know that there are already some really successful examples of landlords working with community groups to provide premises on a temporary basis, to the benefit of both parties.However, we know that landlords may not be aware of the benefits of these arrangements, and community groups may not know who to approach or how to negotiate a temporary contract.This Open Doors scheme will help to overcome these barriers and bring vital services, as well as footfall, to local high streets.This announcement follows the Chancellor’s Autumn Budget which confirmed a new £. billion plan to support and transform the high street.In July this year, we asked Sir John Timpson, a businessman with more than three decades’ experience of what makes our high streets tick, to look at what’s needed to respond to issues currently affecting the high street.He recommended we set up a national body to strengthen local leadership and establish a new fund to support the renewal and reshaping of town centres.So, in this Budget provided a new £ million Future High Street Fund to help local areas adapt to changes and to prepare long-term strategies.The money will help improve transport links, redevelop empty shops, and restore historic properties, keeping our high streets fit for generations to come.We’ve also established a new High Streets Taskforce to help local leaders prepare and implement new strategies for their town centres.Small retail businesses will see their business rates bills cut by a third, saving them up to £ million over two years.These actions will help create a more level playing field for all retailers.It’s against this optimistic backdrop that I will outline my vision for communities at next week’s Locality Convention.I have been clear about my department’s priorities – building the homes this country needs, supporting and strengthening communities, and boosting local growth.Our resolve to deliver on these commitments has been bolstered by a bold budget.Our communities and our high streets will not be left behind.Our journalists title: bosses should give their workers free fruit and bikes to make them feel better health secretary says
story: Matt Hancock suggested firms should also ensure employees have access to counselling to maintain their mental health.And he called on employers to make more effort to help ill workers get back to their jobs.Mr Hancock will this week set out a prevention strategy which aims to stop people getting ill - before they need expensive treatment.The strategy praises a Cornwall-based firm which gives all its employees free fruit in the office and cash to buy a bike, the Sundayreported.Mr Hancock said: Employers need to be more engaged when people arent well, getting them back to work.He said hi-tech gadgets could help Brits stay healthy by monitoring their bodies at all times and sending data to medical experts.The minister said: Where people consent and want to, you can go much further.For instance,you get your genome partially sequenced you can find outyou have a deficiency in a particular vitamin.A vitamin B deficiency leads to a higher instance of dementia but can easily be prevented by eating broccoli.And he suggested kitting out patients with a device which checks whether or not theyve taken the correct medication.

title: mh370 plane intact at bottom of indian ocean investigator claims
story: Author Larry Vance believes the planes fuselage survived the crash and is lying on the floor of the Indian Ocean.Vance dedicated a year and a half to researching his book MH: Mystery solved.He has now blasted the official investigation into the aircrafts disappearance claiming he knows the truth.The doomed jet vanished in March  over the Indian Ocean after setting off from the Kuala Lumpur en route to Beijing.All  passengers and  crew on board the Boeing  are missing, presumed dead.Vance told the Daily Star: The passengers ended up in the Southern Indian Ocean, and are at the bottom of the sea inside the sunken and intact fuselage.The Canadian-born investigator slammed the official investigation and expressed regret about how authorities in Malaysia hadnt gone back to the Southern Indian Ocean to follow his advice.He went on: I honestly believed that once the official investigation team saw the physical evidence that we discovered, and how we interpreted it accurately, they would change their minds about what they thought happened to MH.Unfortunately, and disappointingly, I was wrong.I am not sure why they continue to cling to their incorrect theories and analysis.He also dismissed the theory of Ian Wilson, an amateur investigator who claimed to have found the missing plane in the middle of the Cambodian jungle on Google Maps.Vance said there was no way the plane could have survived a crash into the jungle intact.Images from Google Maps show the outline of a large plane – which could simply be an aircraft flying directly below the satellite which photographed it.But video producer Ian is convinced of his findings and says he  intends to visit the sight to solve one of the greatest mysteries in aviation history.He told the Daily Star: Measuring the Google sighting, youre looking at around  metres, but there looks to be a gap between the tail and the back of the plane.Its just slightly bigger, but theres a gap that would probably account for that.

title: uk weather forecast five more storms before christmas
story: The UK has already been blasted by three named storms this year called Ali, Bronagh and Callum.But it seems that even more punishing wind and rain is on the way from Wednesday as a monster pressure vortex covering virtually all of the Atlantic Ocean barrels up to Britain.Simon Partridge at the Met Office said: There’s an upper trough over the Atlantic which will maintain low pressure and push in from the West through the week.“The thing is, we’ve got high pressure just to the East of us over northern Europe as well so these systems get pushed in from the Atlantic during the week and bump up against the high pressure.“So some of them will fizzle out over the West, but some of them will make their way all the way over to the East.“So it’s a fairly unsettled week ahead with the western UK in particular seeing the brunt of the wettest and windiest weather.And after this week, The Weather Company has forecasted that five more named storms will crash into the UK as Christmas nears, The Mirror reports.The powerful storms will be called Deirdre, Erik, Freya, Gareth and Hannah.If they do arrive, the additional five named storms will take s total to eight after Ali, Bronagh and Callum wreaked havoc earlier in the year.Leon Brown, head of meteorological operations at The Weather Channel, said: Four more named Atlantic storms are expected by early December, plus the risk of a fth named storm before Christmas.Travel disruption and wind gusts over mph in parts of the North and West are expected.Meanwhile, forecasters have predicted perfect weather conditions for Bonfire Night this evening, with clear skies for most parts of the country.But while some areas will be dry with plenty of clear skies, theres a risk of rain across Northern Ireland, north west Scotland and the east coast of England.Met Office forecaster Simon Partridge said: This evening is the big event for Bonfire Night.For most of us dry, fine, plenty of clear skies around. Winds not too strong either.We will see rain across Northern Ireland and the far north west of Scotland and down across the east coast.As the evening goes on you will see a little more in the way of low cloud and hill fog starting to edge its way inland later in the night.Northern Ireland will see the worst of todays weather with a cloudy day and patchy rain this evening.Tuesday is looking like a split picture, with dry conditions in the east and a wetter day in the west.Itll also turn a little bit more breezy before winds really start to pick up towards the end of the week.Wednesday well see heavy, locally thundery, rain and showers with strong winds while Thursday and Friday will probably be showery with some bright or sunny spells.It comes after fireworks displays were called off across the UK on Saturday night as ex-Hurricane Oscar battered the country.Celebrations everywhere from Shropshire to Scotland were cancelled over fears of mph gale force winds.Torrential downpours blasted Scotland, with mm of rain falling in North West Scotland and a yellow weather warning was in place until midnight.But the respite wont last long, with stronger weather conditions to lash the UK later this week.Mark Wilson of the Met Office told the Sun Online: Its a quiet start to the week, but unsettled weather will kick in from Tuesday.We could have gale force winds from Wednesday in exposed areas, particularly in the South West.

title: queen mary saved wilfred smith from the trenches
story: They believe they would not be alive to do it were it not for an act of generosity by the Queen’s grandmother in one of the most moving tales of World War One.For these  men, women and children, aged two to , are the descendants of Wilfred Smith — a real le British version of movie character Private Ryan.In the war, which ended  years ago next Sunday, Wilfred’s mother Margaret saw all six of her sons go off to fight on the Western Front.As she waved goodbye to her youngest, -year-old Wilfred, she poignantly told women on the  at Barnard Castle station in County Durham: “Don’t have boys, they’ll only end up as cannon fodder.”That very day, in February , two of her sons were already dead, killed at the Somme.And by the following summer, mill worker Margaret and her husband John, a chimney sweep, had received five black-edged telegrams from the War Office, each one confirming that one of their boys had died in action.Three of them were never found and today their bodies still lie under the ploughed fields of Northern France and Flanders.But in August that year Queen Mary, we of King George V, read of Margaret Smith’s terrible story in a letter sent to Buckingham Palace.She vowed there and then that Wilfred would be ed home safe to his mother from the front line.Wilfred’s granddaughter Amanda Harrison takes up the story: “Vicar’s we Mary Bircham used to visit the slums of Barnard Castle, where the Smith family lived.“She befriended Margaret, who had  children. After her fth son, Alfred, died of his wounds in a hospital near Boulogne in July , Margaret was terried that Wilfred, her last boy, would also be killed.“So Mrs Bircham took the brave step of writing to Queen Mary and begging her to help save Margaret from any further sadness by bringing Wilfred home.”Amazingly, just days later, the Queen’s private secretary, Edward Wallington wrote back to say Her Majesty had contacted the War Office to find Private Smith in the trenches and order him home.The extraordinary events happened  years before Steven Spielberg made his World War Two film Saving Private Ryan, which echoed Wilfred’s story.Margaret and John Smith’s two years of hell had begun in September , when their -year-old son Robert was killed in the Battle of Flers-Courcelette, on the Somme.He had given up his job as a labourer to join the sixth battalion of his local regiment, the Durham Light Infantry, soon after war broke out in .Robert died just  weeks after arriving in France. He had been among  men who had wrongly been told the Germans were retreating from their position, known as the Starfish Line.At . on the morning of September , , in pouring rain, he was hit by enemy machine gun fire. He was taken to a casualty station where at first he and elder brother George, , who was in the same battalion, joked together. But three days later Robert died from his wounds. He was buried near the town of Albert.After his death, four brothers — George, John, Frederick and Alfred — came home on leave and posed for the photo above that would turn out to be their last together.Wilfred, then working as a mill hand, was not in the picture as he had not yet been called up.On Bonfire Night  George was in an attack on the Butte de Warlencourt, a ft prehistoric burial mound on the Somme, when he was shot through the head by a sniper as he waded through waist-deep mud.His body disappeared under the surface to be lost for ever.His name is carved into the wall of the Thiepval Memorial, along with , other British victims of the Somme who have no grave.Frederick, , was wounded on Christmas Eve  and was sent to recover at home, where he remained until February, .The following week, Wilfred joined up. Five months later, on the opening day of the third battle of Ypres, Frederick was killed.He and his comrades in the th Durham Light Infantry went over the top into a hail of machine gun fire.After driving the Germans from Imperfect Trench they pushed on but dozens, including Frederick, were mown down as they attacked a German fortication. Frederick has no grave but his name can been seen on the Menin Gate in Ypres, where every day since  the Last Post has been played.Margaret’s eldest son, John Stout, , who was married with two daughters, had been born out of wedlock.His name is carved in the Tyne Cot memorial in Belgium after he was killed on October ,  at Passchendaele and his body never found. The Smiths’ nightmare continued the following summer, when their fth son, -year-old Alfred, was wounded in battle on the Ardre river.He died of his wounds at a military hospital in Wimereux, near Boulogne, on July , .Just three weeks later, Queen Mary received the letter begging her to end Margaret Smith’s heartache and bring her last son home.By then Wilfred was a -year–old, battle-hardened Tommy who had fought the Germans hand-to-hand in the trenches south of Ypres.Queen Mary sent Wilfred home where he became a stonemason and chimney sweepHe had survived mustard gas attacks and was training for the final skirmishes of the war at Terdeghem, on the French-Belgian border, when a messenger arrived with orders from Army headquarters to pack his kitbag and go home.Military historian John Sheen, an expert on the Durham Light Infantry, said: “Mrs Smith’s story must have touched the Queen’s heart because taking a man from the line for personal reasons is extremely rare.”Wilfred ed home to Barnard Castle and became a stonemason and chimney sweep, like his dad John, who died in .Despite suffering chronic chest problems from the mustard gas attack for the rest of his le, he lived until he was  and raised five children with his we Hannah.Granddaughter Amanda, , says: “As children we knew a little bit about Wilfred’s amazing story. My mum would tell us some of it but Grandad did not really talk about it.“I think it was probably hard for him in some ways, as he was lucky to leave the war behind — though the people in Barnard Castle didn’t see it that way. Few people can imagine what it must have been like for him to lose five brothers.”On Sunday Wilfred’s daughter Dianne, , Amanda and her daughter Charlene, , son Craig, , and grandson Tommy, two, will plant poppy crosses at Barnard Castle’s war memorial, where the names of the tragic brothers are remembered.Sergeant Fritz Niland – Private James Ryan in the film – was part of the Allied D-Day operation to take back mainland Europe from the Nazis.But when the US military were led to believe that all three of Fritz’s brothers had been killed in action, they sent him home so the family would have one son left.The film, starring Matt Damon as Private Ryan, tells how heroic Captain John Miller, played by Tom Hanks, leads a group of soldiers to track down Ryan amid the chaos of war and send him home.But the real-le twist for Fritz Niland was that while his brothers Preston and Bob had both died fighting in France, his other brother, Edward, had wrongly been listed as having been killed.Edward had in fact been captured by the Japanese after parachuting into Burma in  and held as a prisoner of war.He was freed when the prison camp was liberated in May  and ed to live in the US until his death in  at the age of .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: student begs for a condom on facebook
story: University of Manchester student Jamie Innes, , was so desperate for a condom after a night out earlier this month he resorted to posting to a student Facebook page askinganybody could spare him one during his time of need.The IT student, from Coventry, posted online: Does anyone have a condom I am f***ing desperate This is not a joke I have less than an hour.And he was amazed when just  minutes later a contraceptive hero had obliged - dropping the contraception direct to him in Fallowfield, Manchester.Jamie said: When I posted online, it was a genuine request. I knew somebody would respond as everybody has banter in that group.“I was at the girls house and she was the one who had ran out of condoms. She messaged her house group chat, but nobody ended up replying.“I told her I was posting it on Facebook but she laughed, she found it hilarious. She didn’t think anybody would actually respond about it!Speaking about his saviour, Jamie said the fellow student messaged him directly and asked whether he was genuinely in need of a condom, saying we’ve all been in your shoes.And he said friend with benefits was left in stitches by the entire situation and was completely shocked when the generous stranger eventually arrived with a condom in tow to let them create some magic.Jamie said: He said he was on a bus back from uni and askedI’d been sorted and was only about five minutes away.He just had a spare on him, we had a quick chat when he dropped it off.I really needed one when I posted it, we waited about  minutes, but the magic had passed.We ended up waiting about  minutes more, and eventually the mood came back.“My dad found it pretty funny when he found out, but my mum doesnt know yet.”

title: aldi christmas advert copying coca cola
story: The supermarkets  ad takes inspiration from the iconic truck-themed film called the Christmas Caravan used by Coca-Cola since the mid-s.Aldis Christmas ad once again features Kevin the Carrot in the main role.The character has starred in Aldi advertising since .But this time, Kevin is behind the wheel of a lit-up lorry driving along a snow-carpeted road.Aldi UK said on social media: Our Christmas advertising campaigns are famous for capturing the excitement and anticipation of the festive season in a fun way.This year is no exception, using a sense of humour and Kevin the Carrot to capture the magic of families preparing for Christmas.Social media user Beth ONeill replied: The excitement when I thought the Coca Cola truck advert was on TV but nooo its the Aldi advert!Martin Forsyth wrote: I am loving the Aldi advert parody of the Coca-Cola advert! #SaveKevin

title: brit fliers morning booze airports
story: An hour later the queue for the Brunel bar was  deep as drinkers joined in the early-morning party.Around them stag and hen dos were getting into the swing while waiting for flights to be called.It was a similar story in departure areas up and down the country.And the message from the people enjoying a breakfast tipple was the same — hands off our airport drinks.The fliers were outraged by Government plans to end the tradition of all-day boozing in airport terminals.As The Sun revealed last week, a review by the Home Office is expected to recommend that no alcohol is served before am.But Emily Golding,  — who was enjoying a am drink at Bristol on the way to Amsterdam to celebrate her hen do with friends and family — does not agree.She said: “They just need to do checks as people board the plane to make sure nobody’s been stupid about it.”Another drinker, Andy King,  — flying to Barcelona with ten others to celebrate their friend Darren Perrin’s th birthday — said: “Most people don’t drink at this time in the morning. I wouldn’tI wasn’t going away with the boys. We’re all just having a quick one. You can’t legislate for the idiots that cause the problems.”Mark Smith, , was heading from Bristol to Dublin for a pal’s stag do. He said: “If this legislation comes into place, it’s the airports that are going to be losing out on a heck of a lot of money.I’ve just spent £ on a round of  beers and a little bit of breakfast. It’s chucking money into the economy.”For some travellers, drinking helps with their fear of flying.Worried advertising boss Chris Andrews ordered his first beer at am before a flight from Manchester airport to Malaga. Chris, , from Cheltenham, said: “I’m a nervous flier so I want a beer to steady my nerves.”Nurse Michelle Nowell, , was also drinking at Manchester Airport with her mum Ann and pal Jane Bennett before flying to Tenere.Michelle said: “They shouldn’t be trying to spoil the start of people’s holiday just be- cause a few people can’t control themselves.”Bridget Kizza, , was having a cocktail at .am at Glasgow Airport on the way to Lanzarote. She said: “Alcohol can be more of a problem on the streets but it’s not as bad in airports.”The proposed crackdown would apply to duty free shops and restaurants, as well as the bars. So there would be no carrying on a bottle of booze ready for the first night of the holiday or having a quick glass of wine with breakfast.At Luton Airport the early fliers didn’t want their party spirit dampened.Champagne-swigging account manager Tracy Waldron, , of Peterborough, Cambs, who was heading to Lithuania with her pal Vicki, said: “I haven’t seen any rowdiness today but last time I was here there was a drunk man and that was at . in the morning. His we was really annoyed at him.”Punishments are already strong. Passengers who disrupt a flight can be jailed — andthey cause a flight to be erted they might be forced to pay up to £,.But not everyone thinks that planes and pints are a good mix. Ryanair has called for am to be the earliest that alcohol can be served because the number of booze-related disruptions on planes has doubled in two years.Oliver Bynon — who was flying to Amsterdam from Bristol to celebrate his st birthday with his brother Alex and two friends — agreed.He said: “You wouldn’t drink anywhere  this early. I’m only doing it because we’re celebrating my st. But I think the new law is a good idea.”Dad-of-two Brian Corrway, , travelling to Ireland from Glasgow with his we Linda and their three-month-old baby Oliver, also agreed that time should be called on early airport drinking.Accountant Brian said: “I’m in favour of it. It doesn’t really affect us but we have been in flights with people who are drunk and it’s not very good at that time in the morning.“I guess you do get a small number of people who spoil things for everyone and I don’t see another way of changing it other than limiting the amount people drink before they get on a flight.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theres one man that is able to save us from mays brexit surrender
story: The half-in, half-out scheme would lock Britain into a customs union which prevents outside trade deals and leaves our £billion orce bill as just a down payment.Or so it seems from a series of whispered Downing Street leaks.Theresa May is so secretive she could yet surprise us all with a terric deal for Britain.In the meantime, Brexiteers are bracing themselves for a humiliating UK surrender.Ironically, fears of a botched treaty coincide with signs of growing dismay among EU member states over the shoddy treatment of a long-standing and respected ally.EU negotiator Michel Barnier has been rebuked publicly by EC President Jean-Claude Juncker for the way he has handled talks.Britain’s biggest non-EU allies — America, Japan and Commonwealth countries such as Australia — report “signs of panic” in the capitals of Europe.These focus not just on trade with Britain but on potent issues such as joint defence, intelligence and security.They come at a time of mounting EU anxiety over the disintegration of German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s authority, challenges to the euro from Italy and the rise of right-wing nationalists.Italy’s lethal threat to EU economic rules will come to a head just as we are due to leave next March.French President Emmanuel Macron warns Europe faces the worst instability since World War One.Yet far from capitalising on EU disarray, Mrs May appears ready to leave Britain stranded in what may turn out to be the ruins of the European Project.Her sop to Brexiteers — applying customs checks at factories, not borders — has backfired.“It means they were bluffing about a hard border with Northern Ireland all along,” says one.By taking us into a customs union, even temporarily, Mrs May will turn her back on allies eager for trade deals — led by American President Donald Trump.He planned to make it the highlight of next year’s state visit to the UK.World leaders are shocked by Britain’s cringing, long-winded and cackhanded negotiating style.“Just say you are leaving — and mean it,” says one. “That will get them to the table.”Alarm over “crashing out” is dismissed as scare stories.There is overwhelming confidence the world’s fth largest economy will thrive outside the EU.Ministers will be given a first glimpse of the plot stitched up between Barnier, the PM and Whitehall’s increasingly exhausted Olly Robbins.Mrs May will present them with a stark choice between a done deal and a Marxist Corbyn government.After two humiliating years of fumbled negotiation, this is a dismal prospect indeed.But there is another choice — a new leader ready to put the national interest ahead of naked personal ambition.It won’t be careerist Andrea Leadsom, nor Aid Secretary Penny Mordaunt.Sajid Javid is damaged goods.Brexit supremo Dominic Raab wants Philip Hammond’s job as Chancellor.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt could seize the initiative, but he won’t act alone.So the hopes of many Tories are pinned on Attorney General Geoffrey Cox QC, the breezy Brexiteer who torpedoed Mrs May’s first botched attempt to seal a deal.It was Cox who compared her Chequers blueprint to purgatory — the “second circle of Hell”.He is now marking her homework.Ministers want him to have the final say on the PM’s secret new deal — and for his views to be published.Cox is an eminent lawyer and constitutionalist.He is also a politician who has only recently snfed the sweet scent of political success.He has subsequently been tipped as a dark horse leadership contender.Having seen him in action at the Old Bailey, I think the national interest will come first.The .million who voted for British sovereignty will hope I’m right.“BORED” David Cameron, a nice man with poor judgment, is smarting from abuse over his dream of a peerage and a job as Foreign Secretary. Most blame him for Brexit.But his really unforgivable error was to see “Thatcher” as a dirty word and dodgy Tony Blair as The Master.As a result, he failed to win an outright majority in  and happily shacked up with treacherous Lib Dem Nick Clegg.He bet on another cosy coalition in , only to land a majority and the unwelcome obligation to deliver his promised referendum.Keep chillaxing, Dave.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: john cannan broke promise to find suzy lamplugh
story: Arrogant sex killer Cannan, , offered the ray of hope to Suzys campaigning mother Diana when he was quizzed by police in  when cold case cops re-investigated the case as part of an operation codenamed Phoebus.Amazingly the seven VHS tapes were found dumped in a council run tip in south London and handed to The Sun on Sunday by a concerned member of the public who was shocked when he discovered what they contained.Questioned and Hammersmith police station in west London, over three days, Cannan even offers to take a lie detector test and a truth drug before offering a glimmer of hope to the Lamplugh family before brazenly taking it away.Evil Cannan tells detectives:Ive always said that I will help Mrs Lamplugh in any way I possibly can and Ive given my word, I wont break that word, I will keep that word. Mrs Lamplugh is very important, she obviously is but this isnt just about Mrs Lamplugh.I have a mother, I have a daughter and I have family of my own, whom, I love and who love me to. I have right to protect my own legal positionI genuinely feel that the state is engaged in improper activities and I believe that you are. He then menacingly warns cops:You are pushing me into a corner.He then steadfastly refuses to answer police questions despite them pointing out he has just offered to help the Lamplugh family - he even attacks Diana, who died in  by saying she had surrounded herself with people who do her no favours.Diana went to her grave convinced Cannan was involved in the  abduction and murder of estate agent Suzy who vanished after going to meet a mystery man called Mr Kipper at a house she was selling in Fulham.Cannan told cops Diana had already convicted meof murdering Suzy and even after three jail interviews where he is serving le for the murder of Shirley Banks in , the attempted kidnap of Julia Holman the previous night and the rape of a woman in Reading a year earlier continues to deny any involvement.At one point in the tapes Cannan confesses: I have committed crime, I have done many things wrong in my le, things that believe me I am genuinely sorry for, one or two things I havent even been caught for. Well spoken Cannan even jokes with cops recording the interviewsthey can make him a Genesis tape.After Operation Phoebus ended, the Crown Prosecution Service decided there was insufficient evidence to charge Cannan. But in November  the Met took the unusual step of naming him as their prime suspect for Suzys murder. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britains animals british wildlife photography competition
story: Coupling expert timing with chance encounters, the photographs each give a unique insight into the behaviour and habitat of the animals in Britain.The competition aims to recognise the talents of photographers practising in the UK, while at the same time highlighting the wealth of ersity of Britains natural history.Showcasing the very best of our nature photography, the awards also aim to raise awareness about conservation, British bioersity and our natural heritage.Winners have their work showcased in a national touring exhibition and in a stunning book.Over  images including the winning and commended entries launches at the Mall Galleries, London, commencing Tuesday th November and closing at pm on Sunday th November.

title: universities blasted as not value for money
story: A report published by the Commons Education Committee calls for a sharper focus on the teaching of skills and more support for disadvantaged students.Committee chair Rob Halfon demanded an expansion of degree apprenticeships as well as a fresh look at excessive vice chancellor pay.He said: “The blunt reality is that too many universities are not providing value for money and that students are not getting good outcomes from the degrees for which so many of them rack up debt.“Too many institutions are neither meeting our skills needs or providing the means for the disadvantaged to climb the ladder of opportunity.”The report suggests the “unjustiably” excessive salaries of vice-chancellors have become the norm rather than the exception.It also says they do not represent value for money for students or taxpayers.In the report MPs also say they are “deeply concerned” by the fall in part-time and mature learners.They say universities must offer more flexible learning, including credit transfer, work placements and a move away from the traditional three-year undergraduate approach.The rise in tuition fees in  and the introduction of maintenance loans has led to students from the poorest backgrounds accruing debts over a three-year degree of around £,.The report says the Government should reinstate the means-tested system of loans and maintenance grants.Mr Halfon added: “Our higher education system needs to have a much sharper focus on developing skills.“This could make an important contribution to filling the nation’s skills gaps and solving the UK’s productivity puzzle.“Russell Group universities, including Oxford and Cambridge, should rise to this challenge, up their game and rocket-boost degree apprenticeships.”A Department for Education spokesman said: “Our reforms have seen record rates of disadvantaged -year-olds attending our world-class universities and we want this to continue.That’s why we are pleased to see universities and further education colleges planning to spend more than £ million on measures to improve access and outcomes for disadvantaged students.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: armed forces foreigners recruitment capita
story: The Ministry of Defence is dropping a requirement for applicants from Commonwealth countries like Fiji, Malta and Cyprus to have lived in Britain for at least five years.The change comes as top brass hope to encourage an extra annual , personnel from foreign countries, amid a recruitment struggle.In recent years the business service provider Capita, in charge of recruitment, has been blamed for the failure to hit personnel targets.Mark Francois, a member of the defence select committee, blasted Capita and the recruitment process.He said: “According to evidence given recently to the defence committee, the Army will be lucky to achieve  per cent of its recruiting figures this year.The Army is disappearing before our eyes and will continue to do so until Capita are sacked.”Applicants from every Commonwealth country will be invited to join from early .A Capita spokesperson said they were confident changes being introduced to Army recruitment would deliver better outcomes.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boy asylum seeker ipswich married dad
story: The ft in student is believed to have arrived in the UK from Iran via Germany without paperwork, but told authorities hes .Doubts were raised by pupils at Stoke High School in Ipswich, Suffolk, after he joined this term and a photograph posted on Snapchat went viral.A girl in his Year  class also grew concerned after claiming he had bombarded her with texts and feared he was older than he said.Its since emerged that the student, who speaks in broken English, admitted hes much older than his classmates.One mum, who asked not to be named, told the Daily Mail: My son asked him how old he was and he replied that he was aged  and married with two kids.I feel the school could have done more before allowing him into the school. I also feel a little disgusted about the school not putting the safety of the real students first.Classmates are reported to have found a Facebook profile in his name, which apparently shows him with a full beard, hairy chest and drinking beer.His page listed him as a former architecture student at the Islamic Azad University in Abadan, Iran, who had lived in Erfurt, Germany.A girl, who attends the school, told the Mail On Sunday: He started FaceTiming my friend, sending her messages, asking how close she lived to the school.She was a bit concerned because he seemed so old. He kept messaging her during the night, and in the morning he texted her saying, Hello, how are you She told the maths teacher and was taken to the safeguarding teacher who looked at the messages and said there was nothing sinister about them.Last week, a pupil took a picture of the inidual wearing unorm in a year  lesson, adding the caption: Hows there a  year old man in our maths class.The Home Office has taken on the investigation into the age of the pupil and how he became enrolled at the school, but refused to comment on inidual cases.Sources at the Home Office confirmed that the investigation was being treated “seriously” and appealed for the pupil to be given privacy.In a statement, Stoke High School said: “This is a matter for the Home Office and we have referred it to them.School bosses dropped a suggestion from a previous statement which suggested that the pupil was an asylum seeker.The Sun Online has approached the Home Office and Stoke High School for further comment.

title: el chapo trial brooklyn new york tight security lockdown
story: Elaborate precautions have been taken to protect prosecution witnesses, the jury and a intense security operation will unfold to ferry the drug lord to the fortress court. The notorious Mexican drugs baron had been on the run after escaping from jail via a specially dug tunnel before he was caught in  and extradited to the United States for today’s trial.So its no surprise the courthouse and surrounding area is on complete lock-down. During pre-trial hearings here last Tuesday heavily armed federal officers and bomb-snfing dogs were seen patrolling outside. You can expect the same today and for the cases two month duration. A motorcade transporting the Mexican drug lord across a closed Brooklyn Bridge on his way to a pre-trail hearing last TuesdayAirport-style metal detectors were installed at the courthouse entrance and at the door of the courtroom itself to stop weapons being smuggled in.It is believed a helicopter will ferry him in each day to court from a high-security federal jail in Lower Manhattan.This is to spare New Yorkers the closure of Brooklyn Bridge which is needed to allow a heavily armed motorcade carrying El Chapo.His lawyers have argued this would spark anger among New York commuters and therefore prejudice his trial.Theres even been speculation over a special cell for Guzman being set up in the bowels of the courthouse where he will spend the night as the trial gets underway.The  jurors, who will remain anonymous and sit behind a screen, will be escorted by US marshals to and from court every day.And no ones hiding the ominous nature of the case from them. Questions for them on an initial screening form asktheyve ever heard of El Chapo along with, have you, or has anyone close to you, ever felt fearful of or threatened by people who you thought were associated with drug crimes Meanwhile the same safety measures prosecution witnesses who will be nameless and will be hidden when they testy. The nickname El Chapo means “shorty” in English.But despite his ft ins stature he is accused of running the worlds largest drug cartel, smuggling more than  tonnes of cocaine into the United States, reaping profits of £billion.During the marathon trial in a Brooklyn federal court jurors will have to decide whether he is guilty of  trafficking, firearms and money laundering charges.Hundreds of thousands of pages of documents detailing his drug empire have been brought to court as evidence in what has been described as a watertight case.Prosecutors said recently that Guzmáns sons remain in charge of his vast drug trafficking empire.Guzmán was captured after his whereabouts were apparently given away in an interview he gave to the actor Sean Penn while trying to arrange a film about his own le. A Netflix drama about him has already run to three seasons. Judge Brian Cogan, who will preside over the trial, said: There are not many cases whose allegations are dramatised in popular television productions before the trial has even begun.

title: brexit deal latest theresa may agreement
story: Tory MPs fear the PM is about to abandon Brexit by selling out to Brussels over plans for the Irish backstop in her rush to get a deal within days.And Brussels insiders claim Mrs May is struggling to come up with a deal which can satisfy the EU while still being acceptable to her own backbenchers.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab is understood to have written to the PM, demanding a strict time limit to the backstop which is designed to keep the Irish border open.The minister said Britain should have the right to pull out of the backstop after just three months.He fears that otherwise the UK could be trapped in the European customs union for goodEurocrats decide thats the only way to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic.Irelands hardline deputy PM Simon Coveney hit back today, saying: A backstop that could be ended by UK unilaterally would never be agreed to by Ireland or the EU.These ideas are not backstops at all and don’t deliver on previous UK commitments.Top Eurocrat Sabine Weyand, the EUs deputy chief negotiator, added: Still necessary to repeat this, it seems.Irish PM Leo Varadkar said he wanted to see a deal tied up by the end of the year, but added: A backstop with a limit or expiry date of that nature isn’t worth the paper it’s written on.Mrs Mays spokesman said: We continue to make good progress in the negotiations but there is work still to do.Boris Johnson today took aim at the suggestion Britain could sign up to a form of customs union with Europe.He used an article in The Sun to urge ministers to abandon the stinker of a deal being considered by Mrs May.Jacob Rees-Mogg backed him, asking this morning: Is the Government about to abandon Brexit The PM has been consulting senior ministers over the weekend, seeking to reassure them she wont sign a deal which permanently ties Britains hands.No is playing down reports that a deal could be struck as early as this week - but officials are still keen to hold a special EU summit confirming an agreement by the end of the month.Brussels diplomats told thethe chance of Mrs May being able to get an acceptable deal were just   at the moment.The backstop, which would see Britain staying in the customs union until both sides agree an alternative way of keeping the Irish border open, is the last remaining big issue at stake.Met bosses are worried that crashing out of the EU without an agreement would make it harder to monitor criminal suspects on the move around Europe.They are setting up a new office co-ordinating contingency plans for a No Deal outcome, thereported.Senior Met officer Richard Martin warned colleagues in a report: On a Brexit no-deal scenario, the UK will lose access to European measures, tools and mechanisms.These instruments are used on a daily basis in operational policing and unless the UK can negotiate continued access to them we will no longer be able to use them.The loss of one or more of these measures will have signicant implications for policing.Britain and Europe have agreed to continue working closely on crime and security after Brexit.That will allow both sides to share information about fugitive criminals and access each others databases to fight international crime.But the agreement could collapsepoliticians fail to secure an overall withdrawal deal in the next few weeks.

title: landlord facebook post toddlers pub debate
story: Caroline Roylance, manager of The George in Fordingbridge, said dealing with parents and their children is becoming “more and more” dficult.She described how one baby was “continually crawling around the restaurant and into the bar area” on more than on occasion.She wrote: “We asked the lady once to keep her child at the table as we were very busy and people were tripping over the child while carrying hot food. She said she would try.“As she was leaving she angrily told us that we had ruined her lunch and that we should have asked hershe had slept last night before asking her to keep her child at the table.”Many Facebook users came to Caroline’s defence and one said: “Im sorry Im with the pub on this one.You should teach your children how to behave in a restaurant and crawling around the floor when waiters are trying to serve HOT food is not on.“If one of the waiters tripped on the child and the child was burned Im sure the mother would be trying to blame the pub.”Another added: “It’s not a crèche is it.... keep your kids close or don’t take them!”However some blasted the manager’s post as “childish” and “unprofessional.One said: “I can’t believe that you think it is OK to post things like this about your customers. It is both childish and unprofessional.I am pretty sure a signicant number of families will never want to visit your establishment having read this.”Another added: “Let’s hope that those parents don’t continue to contribute to keeping your business running again then! title: foreign nationals serve british army
story: NewsForeign nationals to be allowed to serve in British Army eventhey dont live in BritainEligibility restrictions are being signicantly loosened in a bid to fill shortfalls in recruitmentShareCommentsBySam Blewett:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailForeign nationals will be eligible to join the Armed Forces in greater numbers, Ministers will announce, as British residency requirements for service are set to be scrapped. The Ministry of Defence will remove the need for Commonwealth citizens to have lived in the UK for five years before applying for service, it will be announced on Monday. An extra , personnel from oversees are hoped to be enlisted to the the Navy, Army and Air Force every year. The move comes as the Armed Forces struggle to recruit enough personnel to fill a shortfall in their ranks. Applicants from nations including India, Australia, Canada and Fiji will be considered for all roles in the forces, without having lived in the UK. Until now, they had to have resided in Britain for five years and their recruitment was capped at a maximum of  per year. The Army will begin the admissions from early next year, while the Navy and RAF will commence the process immediately. Other than the Nepalese Gurkhas and applicants from the Republic of Ireland who can enrol under a special arrangement, those from outside the Commonwealth will still need British citizenship to apply. In April, a National Audit Office report said the full-time military was running at a .% shortfall. An extra , regulars and , engineers were needed to fill the largest gap in a decade, the report added, while intelligence analysts and pilots were also in demand.

title: pay boost tens thousands workers
story: NewsReal Living Wage rises TODAY to £ an hour - giving , workers a pay boostThe wallet-boosting measure will help people employed by , employers who are signed-up to the voluntary schemeShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe “real” Living Wage will climb to pound an hour today - giving more than , workers a pay boost. The voluntary rate, which is paid by employers accredited with the Living Wage Foundation, is pound. per hour more than the Government’s legal minimum, which it calls the “national living wage”. That only applies to workers aged  and over - with independent experts warning it is not enough to live on. The voluntary rate, which activists have dubbed the “real” Living Wage since George Osborne was accused of stealing their branding in his  Budget, rises by p from pound. outside London. Workers in the capital will enjoy a p boost, taking their hourly rate to pound..  The new rates are pound. higher than the statutory living wage for London workers and pound. higher in other parts of the UK. Youre affectedyour company or public sector body has agreed to be a Real Living Wage employer. More than , employers are signed-up to the voluntary scheme, with , businesses joining in the last year, including Liverpool FC, the University of Bristol and Sheffield City Region. Others include IKEA Aviva, Burberry, Nationwide, Nestle and Oxfam. Search the full list of real living wage employers by region here. Living Wage Foundation director Tess Lanning said: “The Living Wage campaign is about tackling the rising problem of people paid less than they need to live.  “Responsible businesses know that the Government minimum is not enough to live on, and today’s new Living Wage rates will provide a boost for thousands of workers throughout the UK. “Employers that pay the real Living Wage enable their workers to live a le of dignity, supporting them to pay off debts and meet the pressures of rising bills. “We want to see local councils, universities, football clubs, bus companies and the other major public and private sector employers in every city commit to become real Living Wage employers. “When they do, thousands of people get a pay rise, but other local employers also follow their lead. “If more of these institutions step up, we can start to build true Living Wage places.” Research suggests poundmillion in extra wages has been pumped into low-paid workers’ wallets since the Living Wage launched in .  Almost poundmillion extra was injected the past  months. If local authorities, universities and sports facilities in towns and cities joined the scheme, an additional , low-paid workers could benefit, according to the Foundation. Analysts calculate the voluntary rate taking into account costs like housing, travel and healthy food, and extras like kids’ birthday presents. Bosses say it helps companies’ reputations, employee retention and boosts staff motivation.  Backing the scheme, Heathrow Airport’s chief financial officer Javier Echave said: “Our colleagues are our most valued asset and deserve nothing less than the Living Wage. “Delivering an ambitious cost-efficiency programme while making responsible decisions for our people is compatible. “Embracing the Living Wage is not just about values, it’s about value. “Fair pay drives engagement, higher productivity and better service to our passengers - a win-win solution to all.”

story: NewsPro-gambling MP says he merely pointed out FOBTs crackdown should be laterPhilip Davies said he merely pointed out to the Culture Secretary that a decision had already been takenShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsPhilip Davies chairs the parliamentary group on betting and gaming "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe head of a parliamentary group which has close ties to the gambling industry has insisted he did not push for a delay to the introduction of a limit to stakes on fixed odds betting terminals . Philip, who I admire on many issues, is very vocal in parliament on behalf of the betting industry. On this occasion I just clearly was not as persuasive.  Mr Davies, who is chairman of the parliamentary group on betting and gaming, said that Mr Wright had been “minded” to bring forward the reduction of the stake to pound to April , but he had highlighted that April  had already been agreed.
