title: hero sir rosslyn wemyss saved
story: NewsHero Sir Rosslyn Wemyss saved hundreds of lives by cutting First World War short by ½ hoursEXCLUSIVE: Wemyss, the British delegate at the signing of the Armistice, fought against Lloyd Georges plan to end the war at .pmShareCommentsByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  NOV NewsAdmiral Hope, General Weygang, Admiral Wemyss, Marshal Foch and Captain Marriot after signing the peace agreement "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt is one of the most haunting and shymemorable dates in our history books – the “eleventh hour of the shyeleventh day of the eleventh month” of  – the day the Great War ended. ButPrime Minister David Lloyd George had his way, that shyunforgettable time and date  years ago this Sunday would not have been so evocative. Worse, it would have cost thousands of lives. A century ago Admiral Sir Rosslyn Wemyss, First Sea Lord – and “Rosie” to his family – was picked as the British delegate at the signing of the Armistice.  The agreement would bring an end to four years of the most bitter and bloody fighting Europe had seen. In a rickety railway carriage, a former dining car turned makesht office, parked up in woodland in Compiegravegne, in northern France, Sir Rosslyn joined the Supreme Allied Commander, Frenchman Marshal shyFerdinand Foch, and the German delegation. After much shuttling between that carriage and the Germans’ own – parked a few metres along the track – the shyArmistice was signed at .am and the ceasefire announced at am.  But today, Sir Rosslyn’s great-great-nephew, Michael Wemyss, , reveals Lloyd George wanted the shyceasefire at .pm, rather than the famous th hour. It would have a been a costly choice... He says: “He was instructed by Lloyd George to ensure the Armistice took effect at .pm. “The story is, Rosie rang King George V and between them decided there was no point holding off, so they brought it forward to the th hour, am.  “Lloyd George wanted to announce it in the Commons and take the glory. George V announced it and Lloyd George had the rug pulled out from under him. “Every hour saved lives.” But siding with the king against the prime minister cost Sir Rosslyn, , dear. “Lloyd George was furious, and shywithheld Rosie’s pound, grant – all the service chiefs got a thank you. They all got earldoms too!” says Michael.  “Rosie was furious. He felt what he had done was to everyone’s benefit other than Lloyd George personally and this was a vendetta.” Sir Rosslyn’s shydecision, backed by George V, a cousin and friend, with whom he had served in the navy, wasn’t his only shyleshyshysaving action during the First World War. He was responsible for getting all the British and Australian troops out of Gallipoli in Turkey in , after their campaign failed spectacularly. “When the army decided to retreat he managed to get all the soldiers off the peninsula without a single death,” says Michael proudly. Alongside him was Captain John Peter Ralph Marriott – and it was to Marriott that Sir Rosslyn turned to assist him at the momentous signing of the Armistice.  Today, his grandson Charles Marriott, , says his ancestor was also always hugely proud of his presence that day. And it was he who phoned the King’s personal secretary to reveal the shydocshyshyument had been signed. “It took him half a day desperately trying to get through,” Charles reveals.  Then only , Charles was gted the blotting paper that was used to dry the ink of the signatures as a memshyento. He always recalled the tense shyatmosphere in the carriage – and the aggressive exchanges between the rather cocky Allied contingent, and their crushed enemy. The Germans had been forced to hand over all their artillery, machine guns, naval fleet, and air force.  “There was quite a lot of rudeness in the carriage,” says Charles. “The German delegation said, ‘We need an Armistice, our people are starving’ – the Navy had blockaded the German ports. And Wemyss told them, ‘You look fat enough!’ “The German replied, ‘As you well know, Admiral, we are the people who don’t suffer in these situations’.” On the French side Eacuteric Beacutecourt-Foch, great-grandson of Marshal shyFerdinand Foch, says his ancestor had a very personal reason for relishing his signing of the Armistice. Foch lost his own son, as well as his son-in-law, Eacuteric’s grandfather, on August , , during the Battle of the shyFrontiers when , French soldiers were killed in less than  hours.  “He did not learn of their deaths for a number of months, the armies were in retreat and it was a great mess,” says Eacuteric, . “News didn’t get through.” Movingly, family man Foch, in deep mourning, wrote to his we nearly ever day during the conflict. “It must have meant all the more to him to finally sign the Armistice,” says Eacuteric of that incredible moment. It was Foch’s carriage where the signing took place – and  years later it was also the location of another historic moment.  When France signed an armistice with the Germans in  during the Second World War, Adolf Hitler ordered that it take place in the same carriage in Compiegravegne, so the Germans could lord it over their enemies. Then the carriage was taken to Berlin and exhibited – until in , as the Nazis realised defeat was coming, they blew up it up in one final act of revenge.

story: NewsHow Meghan Markle used £, Down Under royal tour wardrobe to send subtle messages about her passionsThe Duchess of Sussexs carefully picked clothing symbolised a lot of her beliefs and causes she strongly supportsShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video duchess-sussex-didnt-simply-dress-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle used her royal tour wardrobe to send subtle messages about her passionate beliefs, it has been claimed. The mum-to-be impressed fashion-lovers with her incredible looks - covering everything from comfy casual to red carpet glam from high street names, as well as designer brands. And communication coach Robin Kermode believes the pregnant duchess, , used her strategically picked attire to signal her strongly held beliefs. In total, it is estimated Meghans Down Under tour wardrobe cost pound,. The items of clothing with signicant meanings behind them include her pumps created out of recycled plastic water bottles, and jeans made by female victims of human trafficking and sexual exploitation. With the world of the eyes upon her, some of Meghans outfits have unsurprisingly sold out as fans rush to snap them up. The jeans made by female victims of sexual exploitation  On several occasions during the overseas tour, Meghan opted to wear jeans from Outland - including the Harriet pair, pictured above. The Australian brand was founded by James Bartle after he saw first-hand how human traffickers prey on vulnerable young girls in order to service the sex industry. Determined to making a change, James learnt that once a girl has been rescued and supported through her recovery, a sustainable career path is vital for securing her future. He created the Denim Project, to enable those girls who demonstrated an interest in sewing to put their new skills to use. Outlands team of seamstresses offer positions to those at risk of falling into poverty, and has broadened its mission to set a standard for the treatment and remuneration of young female workers in the garment manufacturing industry. It also sources ethically and environmentally sound raw materials, from organic cotton pocket linings to recycled packaging. After the Duke and Duchess of Sussex announced their engagement, they asked people who wanted to mark the occasion to donate to charities they had picked instead of giving them wedding gts. One of these charities included the Myna Mahila Foundation, which empowers women in Mumbai’s urban slums, by providing them with a trusted network, where they are supported professionally and personally to help them grow as iniduals and businesswomen. Thus Meghans Outland jeans reflect her desire to help vulnerable women which she has spoken so openly about. The vegan leather trainers  Meghan went comfy and casual as she donned white Veja V trainers while on a boat trip in Sydney during the Invictus Games. The trainers got everyone talking as they are environmentally friendly, and made from raw materials sourced from organic farming and ecological agriculture. Some of the shoes also use recycled plastic bottles and many have soles made from wild Amazonian rubber. The French fashion brands founders, Seacutebastien Kopp and Franccedilois-Ghislain Morillion visited clothing and food factories in South America, Asia and Australia while running a nonprofit group — and were appalled by what they saw. So in , they founded Veja in France with the vision of making trainers using the most ecological materials and ethical suppliers they could find. Fashion fans were delighted when they saw Meghan wearing a pair and the duchess is keen on environmental and conservation causes. The recycled plastic bottle pumps  Meghan wore Rothys flats twice on tour, including during a beach clean-up in Melbourne. The pumps are made from recycled plastic water bottles that would otherwise have been destined for landfill - and have been dubbed the most politically correct shoes on the planet by Vogue. The insoles on all of Rothy’s shoes contain recycled foam the rubber soles are made without environmentally stressful black carbon. The yarn comes from plastic and even the packaging’s made from post-consumer recycled materials. Meghan supports charity Surfers Against Sewage, which is a national marine conservation and campaigning charity. It inspires, unites and empowers communities to take action to protect oceans, beaches, waves and wildle. Hugo Tagholm, chief executive of the charity said: Our work as a national marine conservation charity empowers tens of thousands of volunteers annually to protect beaches for everyone. We are currently focused on tackling plastic pollution and this support will help us move towards our vision of Plastic Free Coastlines.” So it is very fitting Meghan wore the pumps during the beach visit - signalling her passion to protecting the sea from plastic. The sustainable brand  The Duchess of Sussex wore a stunning custom-made silk wool cocktail dress in dark navy by Gabriela Hearst at Government House in Wellington. The sustainable luxury brand is based on a less is more approach. Gabriela is a notable feminist designer and political activist. She wanted to create a brand that reflects a slower pace and process: where things are made with care and detail, where tradition is more important than trend, where there is a purpose to every piece, according to her website. She takes into consideration where materials come from and who is making them. Meghan wore the dress to deliver a speech to honor the th anniversary of female suffrage. The empowering dress  Meghan looked sensational when she wore a beautul white Theia dress for dinner with the King and Queen of Tonga. The label is inspired by the Greek Goddess Theia, who had an incredible power to turn everything that she gazed on to light. The Theia dresses are designed to make women feel confident – similar to Meghan’s beliefs. The website explains about their collection: Inspired by the Greek Goddess Theia, this evening wear, bridal and day dress collection was created to bring out every womans inner goddess. One of the original Titans, Theia, who ruled during the Greek Golden Age, possessed the incredible power of light which radiated from her sparkling eyes. All that she gazed upon glittered, becoming luminous and radiant. She imbued gold and silver with their shine. She gave diamonds their fire and rubies and emeralds their sparkle. Her three children Helios the sun, Celene the moon, and Eos the dawn, all continue to bring light in to the world everyday. The woman who wears Theia will be filled with confidence knowing her dress fits wonderfully and looks beautul on her, thus naturally allowing her inner goddess to shine. title: madeleine mccann detective makes 350000
story: NewsMadeleine McCann detective makes £, from book ly accusing parentsGoncalo Amaral made thousands from a book which alleges Kate and Gerry accidentally killed their daughter in ShareByNeil Murphy:,  NOV NewsMadeleine McCann went missing from her parents Algarve holiday home in  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Portuguese police officer who alleges the parents of Madeleine McCann covered up their daughters death has made thousands from a book about the case. Court documents shows Goncalo Amaral raked in over pound, from The Truth Of The Lie which ly claimed Kate and Gerry McCann accidentally killed Madeleine and hid her body. Three-year-old Madeleine McCann vanished from her parents Algarve holiday home in  and no trace of the young girl has ever been found. The couple have always strongly denied having anything to do with her dissapearance.The devastated pair are now in a legal battle with the former Policia Judiciaria officer at the European Court of Human Rights over the smears. A source told the Sun: “If Goncalo Amaral continues to make these outrageous claims then he will find he has a tough fight on his hands.  “Kate and Gerry are not going to let him get away with what he said about them.” Amaral has earned €, since the publication of his book in , according to documents filed at the ECHR. He made a further €, from the sale of his DVD. Demand for the book has seen it translated into multiple languages and over , copies have been put to print. It is believed he is planning to release a follow-up. The McCanns sought to halt the sale of the book by issuing and injunction and began a libel case against the Portuguese detective in .  But he successfully overturned the ruling last April - forcing Kate and Gerry to lodge an appeal in Portugal’s Supreme Court. A source said: “Kate and Gerry still have full confidence the European Court of Human Rights will find in their favour. “It hasn’t altered their determination to carry on searching for their daughter. They have never given up hope and this case is an awful distraction but they feel compelled to do something.”  The McCanns have accused Amaral of waging a relentless battle against them. The former officer pointed the finger at the British class system in an interview which will be aired on Portuguese news channel CMTV. Amaral claims Portuguese prosecutors felt ‘intimidated by the United Kingdom’ and claims the McCanns were given special treatment by British authorities because they were doctors. The ex-policeman refuted claims his officers’ probe was shoddy and says interference from the UK hindered the process.

title: man saved taking life bridge
story: NewsMan saved from taking his own le on bridge hits out at vile online trolls who said "jump"The -year-old says he was shocked when he went on social media and saw insensitive comments from driversShareByAlexandra RuckiChris kitching:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsDrivers were furious over the traffic disruption and didnt care about the mans situation "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad-of-four who was stopped from taking his own le has hit out at online trolls who write cruel and disparaging comments at those in crisis. The man came close to falling from a bridge over the M but was saved when an ambulance crew spotted him as they passed underneath it. Police arrived moments later, shut the motorway and spoke to the -year-old, who has asked not to be named, until he came down. He later went on social media and was shocked by some of the insensitive comments from drivers who were outraged over the traffic disruption and unconcerned about his well-being, he told the Manchester Evening News.  They included Just jump I need to get home, Make sure he gets carted away before I start work and Tell him to get a move on. The man was taken to hospital after he was talked down from the bridge but was left alone in a room and went back to the bridge just hours after. The same police officers brought him back down and stayed with him in the hospital room overnight.Months on, he said he feels awful that police officers were taken off the streets that night and that traffic disruption was caused by the incident. But some of the comments he saw on social media made him feel much worse. Now, he wants to appeal to social media users to think twice before making an off-hand comment - in a bid to raise awareness of the devastating consequences it could have.  He said: To those posting on social media, just think - you never know that could be your mum, or dad up there. Whatthat person looks at the article, reads all of these comments and then goes back out there  It a shame that society feels like that. There is still a lot of stigma about mens mental health and mental health in general. Last week I saw two friends and I was talking to them about when I came out of hospital. They were with a girl Id never met before and she said oh you are a psycho as well. Whatthat was somebody   It could go and set them back. I am thick-skinned, but when I see the comments made about other people I get upset about it. He also explains there is one phrase that he finds particularly damaging, often said to men in his situation. The man said: When it is men people say man-up. My girlfriend at the time kept saying that. It really grates, it hurts inside. It feels like my stomach drops, it makes you feel worse. As a man you are supposed to be one type, but I am a bit feminine - I like things tidy. Saying it to someone suffering from mental health doesnt help. Since he tried to take his own le the man has received treatment at a mental health unit and is now living in supported housing. During his first week out of the hospital he says support workers visited every day, but since then no-one has been to see him.  He was diagnosed with emotionally unstable personality disorder at a young age. Those with the disorder can experience very intense emotions, feel deeply about what others think and can behave impulsively. The man has been told by medics he needs to undergo intensive therapy, but it has never materialised. He said: I have never had therapy. I have spent six years waiting for it. There is that many people getting sectioned daily you just get lost in the system. There is no support, they wont help people until you are suicidal. I am on a mixture of tablets for my mental health and Codeine pain killers. Sometimes I am that knackered I dont go out a lot. I cant work. I was working before, full time. While theres been a lack of mental health services and support since, the dad is hugely grateful to the emergency services who attended the bridge that day. He credits the police officer who spoke to him, and the ambulance crew that first spotted him, with saving his le. The man said: If people hadnt come out I dont think I would be here. I am grateful, especially to the police woman that talked me down, who was really nice. She came back and got me again. She was really lovely, came to check on me as well after to seeI was alright. It couldve been a dferent storyit was a man, she was softly spoken and calmed me down. Its not the first time Ive attempted to take my le, but its the first time I have in three years. If you are going through same thing go and get help. But I know myself, its OK saying get help to others, but when you are in that mind frame you are not thinking about your children. All you think about is ending your le. With me it is emotional, I get angry, I dont feel sociable like everybody , making plans stresses me out. There needs to be more information out there, about what to do. Dont judge peopleyou put a comment up on something like that , think whatthat is your own kids  Elizabeth Simpson, Service Director at Manchester Mind, said: Not all suicides are mental health related but the vast majority are - and unfortunately situations like this show that there remains a lack of understanding about suicide. There is still a lot of stigma, but people in crisis need support and understanding, not judgement and impatience. “With one in every four people experiencing a mental health problem each year there has never been a greater need for services, and Manchester Mind’s vision is of a city that promotes good mental health and that treats people with mental health problems positively, fairly and with respect. Helplines and websitesSamaritansoperates a -hour service available every day of the year. If you prefer to write down how you’re feeling, oryou’re worried about being overheard on the phone, you can email Samaritans at jo@samaritans.org. Childlineruns a helpline for children and young people in the UK. Calls are free and the number won’t show up on your phone bill. PAPYRUSis a voluntary organisation supporting teenagers and young adults who are feeling suicidal.

title: mum shed eight stone year
story: NewsMum shed EIGHT STONE in a year so she could fit into size  wedding gown - and heres how she did itLara Ollerhead began comfort eating and ballooned to a size  following the arrival of her two childrenShareCommentsByChristina WoodNeil Murphy:,  NOV NewsLara and her family at their vow renewal ceremony in Greece "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn st mum who struggled with her weight for decades dropped down to a size eight to renew her vows for her tenth wedding anniversary in a slinky fitted dress. Lara Ollerhead piled on the pounds after having her children - Daniel,  and Sienna,  - and ballooned to a size  due to comfort eating. The -year-old says her expanding dress size restricted her from getting involved with family activities as she became out of breath from climbing just one flight of stairs. However, in March  the regional leader decided to make a change and joined Cambridge Weight Plan [CWP] and within eight months she had dropped down to st.  After losing a whopping st, Lara and her husband Simon Ollerhead, , renewed their wedding vows in August and she was able to wear a size  dress. Lara, from Cuddington, in Cheshire, said: “I was a bit of a comfort eater. Losing weight never really felt within my reach. I was just going to carry on le the same way. “I let my weight get away from me. It is shocking to think about the choices I made that I thought were alright and I know that they would have beenthey were in moderation. “I would start diets and just lose one or two pounds and think that it was never going to happen. “I think being told that as a child that we’ve got to clear our plates as a discipline from and that you have to finish, was ingrained into me. “I couldnt join in on the same things that my husband and children were doing. When they went to a trampoline park I would worry whether the trampoline could take my weight. It was embarrassing. “I would get out of breath after climbing one flight of stairs. I was so tired. My husband is very fit and healthy and the kids would ask why is mummy not coming  Your kids don’t understand.”  Lara, who previously weighed st lbs, completed Step  of CWP which involved having three of their products and one  calorie meals a day. After losing the majority of her weight, in October  Lara began Step  and had two of the CWP products a day along with a  calorie breakfast, a salad for lunch, a  calorie evening meal and ml of milk. Lara said: “When I joined CWP I realised that it could happen and you could do it in a controlled way. It taught me good habits and portion control. “There were normal people who had done it so I knew it was possible. “I feel like a completely dferent person and much more confident, you can’t buy this feeling. It has definitely changed my le. “I don’t worry about what people think and say anymore and I feel confident in my own skin. “I can also get more involved and go to the trampoline park and no longer get red-faced and out of breath. It is all of these little bits that the children are noticing.” Speaking of her vow renewal ceremony in Santorini Lara said: “The ceremony was incredible. It was the perfect setting and so relaxed. It was mazing to renew our vows as a family unit. “I felt a incredible in my dress and having the photos taken. I would have hated this and been reluctant to have had photos taken before”.  Lara said: “We had talked about renewing our vows with the children there but I didn’t think it could ever happen until I found CWP. “It was huge for us because I never thought I would have the confidence to do it. For the children to see us and commend us as a couple is incredible. “I wanted to be comfortable and I wanted to be able to get into a dress I always wanted to wear. He has never seen me this slim before and I wanted a really fitted dress. It was so exciting.” As well as renewing her vows, Lara also took on another challenge and climbed Snowdon, the highest mountain in Wales, with Simon in May  and completed it within three hours and  minutes. She also recently completed the National Three Peaks Challenge to raise funds for a local charity and to hopefully inspire others. Lara said: “It was tough going but not as tough as I thought it would be. He’s always wanted to experience climbing a mountain with me. I didn’t think I would ever have the fitness levels to do it. “Simon did the three peaks last year and I wanted to do it but I knew I wouldn’t be able to keep up with them. I wanted to prove that I could do it this time.  “I became really overcome with emotion when I could see the top but then I couldn’t catch my breath so I had to calm down. “It was the reality that I had conquered something that felt so far out of reach. We never imagined that I could do it and as fast. “I was so determined. I was actually running back down. It just seems mad but it felt brilliant. I am very impressed with myself. Before diet: Breakfast – scrambled egg and bacon or sausage sandwich. Lunch – cheese sandwich and crisps. Dinner – chilli or curry with a full packet of rice and bread and butter pudding for after. Snacks – chocolate bar,  biscuits. Drinks – Fruit juice or squash.  calories After diet: Breakfast – natural yogurt with fruit or porridge with skimmed milk. Lunch – salad with prawns, balsamic vinegar and lemon. Dinner – Homemade curry or chilli with caullower rice, homemade burgers with salad or vegetables. Snacks – CMP lemon bars, natural yogurt, fruit, carrots and hummus. Drinks – water, black coffee, black tea.  calories

title: princess diana revealed exactly how
story: NewsPrincess Diana revealed exactly how she made William and Harry dferent to the rest of the royal familyThe Princess of Wales wanted to effect change in the monarchy - and she used William and Harry to do soShareCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsIt wasnt just about having fun "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEvery time Prince William and Prince Harry step out and greet the public, there are countless messages on social media about how their mum Diana would have been so proud. But people wont realise exactly how true this is - as the two princes really are fulfilling a dream their mother had for them more than  years ago. In an interview with Martin Bashir for Panorama in , Diana spoke about her two boys and how she was raising them, in response to a question about whether the monarchy needs to adapt and change in order to survive. Diana replied: I understand that change is frightening for people, especiallytheres nothing to go to. Its best to stay where you are. I understand that. But I do think that there are a few things that could change, that would alleviate this doubt, and sometimes complicated relationship between monarchy and public. I think they could walk hand in hand, as opposed to be so distant.  When Bashir asked what Diana is doing to effect change in the monarchy, the princess responded by telling him how she was raising her young sons. She said: Well, with William and Harry, for instance, I take them round homelessness projects, Ive taken William and Harry to people dying of Aids - albeit I told them it was cancer - Ive taken the children to all sorts of areas where Im not sure anyone of that age in this family has been before. And they have a knowledge - they may never use it, but the seed is there, and I hope it will grow because knowledge is power.  Bashir replied: What are you hoping that that experience for your children - what impact that experience will have on your children  And Diana responded: I want them to have an understanding of peoples emotions, peoples insecurities, peoples distress, and peoples hopes and dreams.  Prince Harry has been praised on several occasions in his recent royal tour of Australia, New Zealand, Fiji and Tonga. While climbing the Sydney Harbour Bridge, palace aides told him to move on from his conversation with a grieving woman - but Harry refused to do so.The Duke of Sussex had spent  minutes chatting to Gwen Cherne, whose husband committed suicide last year. When his staff tried to move him along to somebody , Gwen said Harry responded: Im in a middle of a conversation, and Im not going to leave this.  Gwen was joining Harry to kick off the Invictus Games - a competition he founded to help wounded military men and women. The Duke also makes regular visits to Lesotho, in Africa, where he first visited on his gap year and made a special connection with communities there.William, too, has been praised for his kindness and warmth towards the public, speaking to them as though they are old friends.Just a few weeks ago, while meeting young people at a Radio  Teen Awards reception in Kensington Palace, Will made them feel right at home.He told a teen who had been bullied for dancing: George is doing dancing as well, he loves it.My mother always used to dance. She loved dancing. Andit’s something you love, you do what you love. Don’t let anyone  tell you otherwise. Keep at it.”  The princes are also carrying on work their mother started.Prince Harry is patron of leading landmine charity The HALO trust, and William is president of the Royal Marsden Hospital - the same cancer institution his mother represented from  until her death in . Dianas visits to homeless charities obviously had a lasting effect on her boys. In  William slept rough on London streets in order to raise awareness of the issue.

title: ross edgley sets foot land
story: NewsRoss Edgley sets foot on land for first time since June  after becoming first man to swim round BritainIncredible Ross Edgley, , has front-crawled almost , miles over  days to become first person to swim round UKShareCommentsByMatthew Young:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video watch-ross-edgley-sets-foot-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailExtreme sportsman Ross Edgley emerges from the water for the first time in  days after becoming the first person to swim around Great Britain. Ross, , was joined for the final mile of his ,-mile journey by  other swimmers,  of whom had swum the English Channel. He did his last few strokes of front crawl before coming ashore where he had begun, in Margate, Kent. He said: “I had to put my goggles on. I was getting really emotional.  “I thought I was going to fall over. And then I started running – that was a mistake. I was really wobbly. “It feels a bit weird. Feels a bit too solid for my liking.” He left Margate on June  and then circumnavigated Britain by front crawl in a clockwise direction. He had expected it to take  days and told his family “sorry I’m late” as they greeted him alongside hundreds of others on the beach. During his epic feat, Ross’s tongue started to disintegrate due to the exposure to salt water and he was also stung in the face by a jellyfish. Ross, from Grantham, Lincs, swam for to  hours a day, on occasions through the night. He battled strong tides and currents in cold water, storms, and swimming into winter, suffering shoulder pain and wetsuit chafing. He was Ross Edgley, , has front-crawled almost , miles over  days to become first person to swim round UK .  Ross’s odyssey has been compared to that of Captain Matthew Webb, who in  became the first person to swim the English Channel. While more than , swimmers have since made that crossing, few are likely to follow in Ross’s wake. He was thrilled by his reception early yesterday morning. He said: “That was unbelievable. You won’t find many other sports where people will come out in November, at five o’clock in the morning, just to swim out for a mile. “That represented what I love about open water swimming. “Because I’ve had my face in the water for so long now I didn’t know – I thought it was just going to be my mum and my dad with a pizza.” He entered the Guinness Book of World Records on August , on day , for the longest staged sea swim. It is his latest record-breaking feat. In , he did a rope climb equivalent to the height of Mount Everest in  hours, two months after doing a marathon pulling a car. And his mantra on challenges  “Be naive enough to start and stubborn enough to finish.”

title: teen yob who pelted vulnerable
story: NewsSnapchat yob who pelted vulnerable woman with flour and eggs says HES now too scared to leave his homeCohan Semple says hes received "death threats from random people" after the sickening attack on mum-of-one Janice Morris in Bury St Edmunds, SuffolkShareByLouis SmithSophie Evans:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsCohan Semple humiliated the vulnerable woman by pelting her with flour and eggs "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenage yob who humiliated a vulnerable woman by pelting her with flour and eggs is now too scared to leave his home, it is reported.Cohan Semple says hes struggling to leave his house amid death threats following the sickening attack on -year-old Janice Morris. The teenager was among five boys who targeted Janice as she sat on a park bench in Suffolk in what a court heard was a despicable attack.An image showing them smiling and pointing at their cowering victim sparked widespread revulsion after being posted on Snapchat and Facebook. Until this week, the boys - all between  and  years old at the time - had had their identities protected because of their age. But Semple turned  last week, meaning he could be unmasked for the first time. Speaking out yesterday, the teenager - who pleaded guilty to threatening behaviour - described how he has received death threats from strangers.He told Sun Online: I’m struggling to leave the house at the moment. Since those pictures have gone on Facebook, I’ve had death threats from random people. Askedhe wanted to apologise for the attack in Bury St Edmunds, he reportedly said he was not ready because of the death threats sent to him online.Semple and his friends faced online abuse and direct threats from people who were sickened by the picture after it was shared online. Yesterday, presiding magistrate Simon Islett told the younger members of the group they could have faced jail termsthey were a few years older. He described the incident as a despicable attack on a vulnerable woman and said it was “terrying” for the mum-of-one.Mr Islett told one boy: “She didn’t know what was going to happen or what the outcome was going to be.  You have got to put yourself in the victim’s place and consider your actions and the effect it might have on them.” Janice was sitting in a park when she was approached by Semple and the group. Ipswich Youth Court heard they began asking questions about drugs before one of the boys spat in her face. Prosecutor Wayne Ablett said: He came from behind the bench and spat at her, with spit landing on her face. She said, What did you do that for  She recalls the boy laughing at her, then spitting at her again. Magistrates heard the group disappeared for around  minutes, then ed with flour bought at a nearby shop. Mr Ablett said: These items were chucked at and thrown at her body, covering her completely in flour. The boys were still laughing. She was spat at again and one of them had taken a photo of her. She heard one of them say, Were filming it.  The boys were arrested after the incriminating photo appeared on Facebook in July this year. Janice suffered no physical injuries but was left severely distressed by her ordeal. Semple, who admitted threatening behaviour, lives in Bury St Edmunds with his mum. The court heard since the incident he had received death threats, and felt remorseful and sorry for what happened. Declan Gallagher, defending Semple, said: He took the photograph and put it on his own Snapchat. One of his circle then took a screenshot of that, then it went onto Facebook, then it went beyond. He was released on bail, to be sentenced at an adult court on December . Four other boys, aged , ,  and , admitted the same offence yesterday and were sentenced to -month referral orders. They were also ordered to pay pound each in compensation to the victim. A sixth defendant, aged , denied using threatening behaviour and will face trial at the youth court on February .

story: NewsText messages sent by couple who left baby girl to die in monstrous cage revealedLauren Coyle, , and her boyfriend Reece Hitchcott, , were found guilty of child cruelty at Liverpool Crown CourtShareCommentsByJonathan Humphries:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsEllie-Mays mum Lauren Coyle was cleared of manslaughter "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailText messages sent by a mum and her boyfriend who left a baby girl to die in a monstrous cage have been revealed. The window had also been blocked with a mattress and there were no lights. Ellie-Mays mum Lauren Coyle, , and her boyfriend Reece Hitchcott, , were cleared of manslaughter, the Liverpool Echo reported. After almost seven-and-a-half hours of deliberations, the jury found the pair guilty of causing or allowing her death, one count of child cruelty by caging the child in her bed, and another count of child cruelty by restraining her in the bed.  Their lodger, Connor Kirby, , of Liverpool, was found not guilty of all of the charges A post-mortem examination carried out by Dr Alison Armour, a Home Office consultant forensic pathologist, concluded the childs death was caused by forcible restraint by ligatures in a face-down position complicated by hyperthermia. During the trial, prosecutor Christopher Tehrani, QC, read out a series of text messages between Coyle and Hitchcott, which between the couple following Ellie-Mays birth. Hitchcott sent a message which read: I will get it dont worry why the f*** have been like this today i have done f*** all wrong.  Coyle replied: Dont treat me like that bloody let you borrow pound when that could have gone on Ellies trainers. Hitchcott replied: Alright for you to be like that with me wtf Coyle replied: Cant be arsed with it anymore you owe money now pay it. Coyle soon began to complain to her boyfriend that Ellie-May was keeping her awake at night. Her text read: Ellie keeps waking up have to take in living room dont want to go to bed yet. Coyle often messaged her boyfriend while he was at work, the court heard.  On one occasion Hitchcott sent her a message which read: I love you baby this one of the ways it will teach her slowly that she needs to sleep on her own. On February   Coyle posted a message on her Facebook page which read: Finally got my little princess in a routine in her big bed. She is growing up far too fast. Coyle sent a message to Hitchcott which read: Stressed with Ellie. She was biting me so I put her in her room. She is banging her head off the walls. I have smacked her loads too. Hitchcott replied: I will sort her out when I come home. I will put her in her room. Coyle replied: I literally feel like jumping n front of a train. So stressed.  Hitchcott replied: I will sort it out baby. On another occasion Coyle sent a text to her boyfriend which read: There she goes ahead banging her f***ing head again. On March  Coyle sent a message to Hitchcott which read: Ellie playing up again shoved her in her room. Hitchcott replied: She will behave when I am home ha ha. Mr Tehrani also told the court that Ellie-Mays medical condition deteriorated in the months leading up to her death. The toddler suffered from vomiting and diarrhea, and a doctor said that she was suffering from gastroenteritis. The case was adjourned for sentencing at a later date.

story: NewsTower of London lit up by , flames in poignant tribute to fallen WWI heroesThe flames filled the empty moat which encircles the Tower of London and the ceremony was held to mark the end of WWIShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video tower-london-lights-first-flame-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tower of London was bathed in the light of around , flames which filled the empty moat encircling the landmark to mark the centenary of the end of the First World War. A ceremonial Beefeater guard began the lighting ceremony by bringing a flame down from the tower into the moat, which had been submerged in smoke. Dozens of representatives from the armed forces and volunteers then used the flame to ignite thousands of other torches staked into or placed on the ground underneath the tower, bathing the barren moat in light. Midshipman Balraj Dhanda of the Royal Navy, a volunteer who helped light the flames, described the spectacle as really, really powerful.  I think it creates the right atmosphere for people to have their own personal reflections and gives people time with their own thoughts, he added. It took around  minutes to light the flames, which then burn for roughly four hours. The ceremony was accompanied by a specially commissioned sound installation featuring choral music, as well as words from war poet Mary Bordens Sonnets To A Soldier. The ceremony was amazing, according to Dick Harrold, governor of the Tower of London.  He added: What is so special about it is it means many dferent things. The message with the sound is not focused so much on those that were lost, but those that were left behind, the bereaved and others who were affected by war. The success of the  display of poppies at the tower meant Historic Royal Palaces, who maintain the landmark, were keen to mark the centenary of Armistice. He added: But, of course, we couldnt do poppies again. Spectators gathered on vantage points around the tower to witness the spectacle.  A minutes silence was also observed. The ceremony, named Beyond The Deepening Shadow, will be repeated each night until the final showing on Remembrance Sunday. Members of the public can watch the spectacle for free.

title: what would make modern day
story: NewsopinionWhat would we make of a modern day Guy Fawkeswe bumped into him under Parliament A war veteran angered by broken promises stood in the undercroft of the Houses of Parliament with  barrels of gunpowder, some coal and firewood, with matches in his pocket  years ago todayShareByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  NOV Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailImagine you find an Afghanistan war veteran with a bomb under the Houses of Parliament. It’s just you, him, and the bomb, and you talk to him to buy yourself some time while hoping someone comes along, calls the police, does the decent thing. So you chat to the soldier. There are lots of things he could be angry about with the people currently sitting above you – fraud, smears, lies, paedophiles, cock-ups, poor mathematics, migrant-bashing – but the thing he hates most of all is the Military Covenant. Not the idea of it, which is to ensure armed forces personnel suffer no disadvantage due to their service and sometimes get preferential treatment because of it. Nor the way it was enshrined in law in  amid much fanfare and the Prime Minister promising to “treat people with the dignity they deserve”. No, he’s angry about the fact that within a year of it being made law Parliament pissed on it. He’s angry that war veterans like him were made redundant just days before they qualied for a pension, while politicians facing reform to their own pensions could get a higher salary to make up for it. Hes angry that veterans who gave their lives and health - and in some cases that of their wives and children as well - have reasonable claims for recognition, supported by scientic research, litigated past the point of their own deaths to avoid a payout. Hes angry at the state of military housing, at the way his family after his redundancy have to go on a council waiting list, at howthey rent privately a grasping landlord will rack up the rent while housing benefit is cut and slashed as politicians call them scroungers. Hes angry about his mates killed for want of proper equipment, at a Prime Minister helping the private defence industry quite literally make a killing with state-funded trips to dictatorial regimes, and hes angry at mealy-mouthed letters from politicians thanking him for his service and telling him theres nothing they can do. As he talks you realise youre angry, too. Youre angry about paying for people on pound, a year to have an extra house, at jobs for their wives and children, at a mooted % pay rise they claim they can’t refuse from a pay body they set up themselves. Youre angry about their dodgy rental agreements, their non-existent mortgages, their invoices, their pitul excuses, at the physical evidence of these historic abuses being shredded on the basis they need their privacy protected. You’re angry about the fact it took two years of appalling allegations about paedophiles infecting almost every institution in British le – the BBC, the NHS, children’s homes, Parliament itself never mind your local kebab shop – before the Government was stirred into organising an inquiry. And then mis-organised it so badly the first two chairmen had to resign over connections to the very people they would have been inquiring into.   You dont like politicians pitting you against your neighbours and saying people who dont draw their curtains in the morning must be on benefits, rather than a night sht. Youre perplexed about new schools with teachers who dont need any qualications, about hospitals rewarded for letting people die, about a minimum wage which isnt enough to live on. You wonder about the worth of parliamentarians who tell the terminally ill to get up and work. You wonder how disabled people will have a better le without the allowances they need to pay for independent living. You question how your already-overworked GP and children’s teacher are going to fit any more hours in. You look at your local postmaster, corner shop owner, launderette, binman, cabbie, cleaner, nurse, teaching assistant, council operative and heaven knows who  and wonder how, precisely, we’d manage without migrants. Perhaps you look at your own bloodline. Perhaps you look at the history books. Perhaps, very faintly, you hear the echoes of bad people from bad times. And more than anything , you remember how a man who wanted to be Prime Minister in  promised parliamentary reform. There was a manesto which offered you: “The direct power to recall MPs found guilty of wrongdoing without having to wait for a General Election… to cast a vote of no confidence in their elected representative and bring an end to the concept of the ‘safe seat’.” There was also a Coalition agreement promising an elected House of Lords,  open primaries, an end to parliamentary perks, recall, and constitutional reform which would give us “a new politics” we could be proud of. You think about the fact million people who could vote last time didn’t bother. You think about the fact million people have removed themselves from the electoral register since . You think about a House of Lords packed with donors and cronies, the holding of a mere  local primaries, perks that still include free snuff, a recall bill backed by a mere % of Tories, % of Labour and % of Lib Dems, and a politics that seems just as sleazy and corrupt as ever. You stand there, feeling angry, and think about how  years ago today a war veteran with  years fighting behind him who felt oppressed and angry about promises the rulers had broken stood in the undercroft of the Houses of Parliament with  barrels of gunpowder, some coal and firewood, and matches in his pocket. You think about how that veteran was seized and dragged before the king, how he and his fellow plotters were tortured with the rack and other instruments for ten weeks to produce confessions, and how after a show trial they were taken to the yard outside Parliament where the politicians could all watch as they were hung by the neck, cut down while still alive, castrated, disembowelled, and cut into pieces. Perhaps you know enough to remember that despite injuries so bad he could barely sign his own confession, Guy Fawkes was brave and quick enough to jump from the scaffold before the executioner could stop him, breaking his own neck and saving himself the extra agonies the state wanted to visit upon him. You wonder why we still celebrate the capture, torture and death of that man with a bonfire and fireworks, that it was laid down in law we had to do so whether we agreed or not and that it was used to persecute others who shared his faith. You wonder why we all forgot why he was so angry or that after he was gone the oppression for people like him simply got worse, and lasted for more than two centuries. Perhaps youd also wonder what wed do to that Afghanistan veteranhe was caught red-handed with his bomb under Parliament, and how it would compare to what we would dohe turned out to be a Muslim convert. You look over your shoulder at the door, and youre glad no-ones come along yet. Maybe you wish him luck, and tell him that as Fawkes said on the rack a desperate disease requires a dangerous remedy. Maybe you will try to talk him out of it, or go to find a policeman in the hope hell get help and the people who put themselves above will finally listen to those left below. Me, well I think Id quietly turn around, close the door, stick my elbow in the fire alarm and then let him get on with it.

title: zizzi salisbury reopen after novichok
story: NewsZizzi in Salisbury to reopen after Novichok poisoning as staff get counsellingThe restaurant was at the centre of the Salisbury spy poisoning investigationShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  NOV NewsThe Zizzi restaurant was closed as members of the military work in the Maltings shopping area nearby "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Zizzi restaurant at the heart of the Novichok poisoning attack in Salisbury will reopen tomorrow after staff received counselling. Traces of the nerve agent were found in the city following the poisoning of Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia, after the pair had eaten at the restaurant. It has closed for the eight months since as specialist military teams carried out a meticulous clean-up and police investigated the attack. But the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs has now declared the restaurant safe and, after a complete refurb, it is ready to reopen. Phil Boyd, operations director at Zizzi, said staff had been offered counselling and been retained on full pay during the closure.  I think it has been a fairly dficult time for all of our team.We have retained them on full pay, we have had regular contact with them, we sent a small support team down to the restaurant to make sure that they were well looked after, he today told The . Our priority was initially to make sure that everyone was feeling well and once we knew that all of our team were fit and healthy we made counselling available to them.  The community in the Wiltshire cathedral city has largely welcomed Zizzis decision to remain at the premises. Alistair Cunningham, chairman of the South Wiltshire Recovery Coordinating Group, said the reopening of the restaurant represented a signicant step forward for the city and showed it had ed to normal. “Work continues to restore visitor confidence and provide support to local traders and businesses.

title: final words sam ballard who
story: NewsHeartbreaking final words of Sam Ballard who died  years after eating toxic slugRugby player Sam Ballard has passed away aged , several years after he ingested the toxic slug for a spontaneous dare as a teenagerShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsSam was a talented rugby player before the dare ended his career before it had even begun "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe heartbreaking last words of the rugby player who died after eating a slug eight years ago have been revealed. Popular teenager Sam Ballard ate the toxic creature for a spontaneous dare when he was just . Sam was rushed to hospital where doctors told him he had been infected with rat lungworm. While the disease is usually found in rodents, snails and slugs can become infected as they often eat the rats faeces. The excrement contains a parasite which is known as Angiostrongylus cantonensis. He spent  days in a coma after developing eosinophilic meningo-encephalitis. Earlier today it was revealed Sam had died at the age of , shortly after telling his mother I love you. Ballard died last Friday, Lisa Wilkinson, a presenter on Australian TV show The Sunday Project, said.  “We have some sad news for you now, she said. Earlier this year we brought you the story of Sam Ballard who, on a dare from his mates, ate a slug. He contracted rat lung disease with devastating effects.  “His friends have stuck by him ever since. On Friday, Sam passed away, surrounded by his family and loyal, loving mates. “His last words to his mum: ‘I love you’.” Ballard ingested the poisonous mollusc at a friends party in  in Sydney after accepting a dare. His friend Jimmy Galvin explained later: We were sitting, having a bit of a red wine appreciation night, trying to act as grown ups and a slug came crawling across.  The conversation came up, Should I eat it  Off Sam went. Bang. Thats how it happened. He didn’t become sick immediately, but complained of serious pain in his legs in the days after. He was worried it might’ve been a symptom of eating the slug, but his mother told him not to worry: “No-one gets sick from that,” she said.  Sam was worried he might have developed Multiple sclerosis, like his father, but that was ruled out. When Sam woke from his -day coma he found he had become a quadriplegic. The parasite caused an infection on the brain. Sams mother, Kate, always remained hopeful that her son would walk and talk again. But she had resigned herself to the fact that he would never be the same again.  She said: Its devastated, changed his le forever, changed my le forever. Its huge. The impact is huge. Sam was released from hospital three years after falling ill and was able to move around in a motorised wheelchair. His friends raised money for the round-the-clock care he required with Sam suffering seizures. Among his other problems were an inability to control his body temperature. He needed to be tube fed. In  Sams disability allowance of , was slashed to just ,, which left the family in debt.

title: new zealand fisherman pulls 18
story: NewsNew Zealand fisherman pulls floating -month toddler ALIVE from oceanGus Hutt was fishing while on holiday on the North Island of New Zealand and at first thought the boy was a dollShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsToddler Malachi Reeve is still himself after the near-drowning, mum Jessica Whyte says"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA fisherman in New Zealand rescued an -month-old toddler from the ocean in a freakish miracle. Holiday camper Gus Hutt was out fishing when he spotted a small figure floating in the water. At first he thought little Malachi Reeve was a doll but when the tot let out a squeak he realised it was a baby. The boy had escaped from his parents tent and ended up in the ocean. Mr Hutt told the NZ Herald: As he floated past I thought he was just a doll. So, I reached out and grabbed him by the arm even then I still thought it was just a doll. His face looked just like porcelain with his short hair wetted down, but then and he let out a little squeak and I thought oh God this is a baby and its alive.  Mum Jessica Whyte said it felt like a nightmare when she discovered her young son was missing and that her heart had stopped beating. She told Stuff that she was woken by the camp manager at Matata Beach to the news her son had been found floating in the sea. Whyte said the news dealt like a sick joke when she was told at .am on October  and it was horrible in between hearing that and seeing him.  I dont think my heart [beat] from hearing that to seeing him. I dont think my heart worked, she said. It was pure luck that Mr Hutt had been fishing there to save the boy. Usually he walks straight out to camp to fish from the beach, but on the day in question he decided to walk  metres to the left.  After ing to check his lines at .am, he saw the seemingly leless baby floating in the water. He was floating at a steady pace with a rip in the water. If I hadnt been there, orI had just been a minute later I wouldnt have seen him, said Hutt. He was bloody lucky, but he just wasnt meant to go it wasnt his time. Rebecca Salter, the co-owner of Murphys Holiday Camp told the BBC: Apparently the baby had been very excited to be on the beach. It was the couples first night staying here. Its the first time theyve been here. Hutt, who is a fisherman and one of our regulars, spotted the baby. [They brought the baby to us], we wrapped him up in towels and Sue went to inform the babys parents. The baby had escaped from his parents tent by undoing the zipper, and then made his way into the ocean. It came as a shock to everyone. It was a very, very lucky result... it could have been a very tragic incident, said Mrs Salter. Its a freakish miracle.

title: woman faints uncle walks family
story: NewsWoman faints when uncle walks into family home - two months after his funeralAigali Supugaliev, , was presumed dead after a DNA test was performed on decomposed corpse found hear his home in Tomarly in KazakhstanShareCommentsByWill Stewart:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsAigali Supugaliev poses with his tombstone plate "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man walked through the door of his family home - two months after his funeral. A relative who saw her dead uncle alive and healthy “almost collapsed with a heart attack”. Aigali Supugaliev, , was reported missing from his village of Tomarly in Kazakhstan on  July. Two months later a DNA test on a decomposed corpse discovered close to his home found a . per cent likelihood that this was Supugaliev - the maximum probability such a test can give. A death certicate was duly issued and his brother Esengali organised a funeral and the family held a wake. The dead man was buried in a Muslim ceremony in a ceremony in Zhuldyz district.  “When Aigali came home alive and healthy, my daughter Saule, seeing her dead uncle, almost collapsed with a heart attack,” said Esengali. “The DNA analysis had confirmed this was my brother. “We believed the results and conducted all the funeral and memorial rites. “I spent so much money on it. But it is not even about the money. “Who have we buried  Maybe his relatives are looking for this person.”  Unmarried Aigali posed for a picture with his gravestone which his family had been poised to erect at the moment he walked through the front door. He explained that he had been offered a job working on a distant farm and had decided to take the four month post, not thinking to inform his relatives. His sister in law Aiman Supugalieva, , said: “Glory to Allah that he ed alive, but we are going to prosecute the experts who gave such a DNA result.” The test had used his nail clippings, according to local reports. The scientist who carried out the test Akmaral Zhubatyrova said: “It is impossible to state unequivocally that this is the body of a person, relying only on the results of the DNA examination. “We should not forget about the remaining .%.”

title: defensive duo set to make dundee united return for queens encounter
story: Defenders Paul Watson and Jamie Robson look to be on course to make the squad for Dundee United’s home clash with Queen of the South on Saturday.Watson is back in training after recovering from the thigh knock that ruled him out of the clashes with Inverness and Dunfermline.Robson, meanwhile, hasn’t started under new boss Robbie Neilson and missed out on a place on the bench last week because of an ankle problem.The full-back, though, is expected to be back working with the rest of the squad from tomorrow and, as long as he suffers no reaction, he will be available this weekend.That would leave only long-term absentee Lewis Toshney on the injured list and there was even some good news on his latest setback when he turned an ankle in training last week.“It’s not as bad as we thought and I’d expect him back,not next week, the week after,” said Robbie.While he’s delighted to be steering clear of injuries, Robbie knows they may strike at any time and wants to be readythey do.“You want everyone fit but very rarely does it happen.“That’s why you want the guys who aren’t in the starting XI to continue to work hard. They have to be ready to come in when they’re required.”Robbie also believes club captain Fraser Fyvie is getting close to full match fitness after his long absence until last month because of knee surgey.“I think he still has a little bit to go and I think he will probably agree with that.“When you’re out for nine months like he’s been then you can take six, eight games to get to it.“He’s getting stronger with every game and he’ll be stronger this week.”

title: dundee council pockets 5000 from selling electoral roll data
story: Dundee City Council has made nearly £, from selling electoral roll data in the last two years, new figures have revealed. vw, px"  Information provided to the Tele showed the local authority has made £,. from selling copies of the electoral register since December , the most recent statistics available.Of that, £. of the sales were to credit reference agencies such as Experian, Callcredit and Equax, who use the data to confirm personal details when dealing with credit applications.The other £ was made by selling the electoral roll to the Scottish Courts and Tribunals Service, who use it to carry out jury selection.There are two types of electoral roll which can be sold by councils: the “full” register, and the “open” register, which can be opted out of and sold to private firms.The council did not sell any copies of the open register in the period, according to the data.

title: dundee defender odea issues rallying call for huge clashes with motherwell and st mirren
story: Dundee defender Darren O’Dea has called on every member of the squad to play their part in what he says is a “huge chance” to haul themselves off bottom spot over the next couple of weeks.After Celtic’s - thumping of the Dark Blues on Wednesday, O’Dea is happy to have a chance to put that defeat out of mind at Motherwell today.With  losses in their first  games, a change of fortunes is badly neededthey are to get themselves off bottom spot in the Premiership table.He said: “You don’t come off the pitch on Wednesday even wanting to look at any positives – the only positive is already today we have an absolutely colossal game.“You can’t write off a game like Wednesday. I know I didn’t forget about it, it’s hard to take but I do much prefer having a game this close rather than have to sit on that Celtic defeat for a week.“Celtic are a top side and they showed it – we showed we are a side in between at the minute.“We had a gameplan and we felt relatively comfortable to begin with but, having been on the other side with Celtic, you know when you get that first goal it drags the opposition out and away from your shape a bit.“We were a bit naive and, out of probably eagerness to try to get back into it, we’ve gone into half positions where some are pressing and some are sitting off which becomes disjointed and we got punished.“We have big games coming up and, thankfully, there’s not the chance to dwell on it which you don’t want to do.”With the Steelmen just five points ahead after a poor start to the Premiership season themselves and then th-placed St Mirren at Dens to come next weekend, the Irish international says it’s “imperative” they start adding to their solitary victory this season.“Motherwell is huge. We can’t afford to look ahead but there is a patch of games where it’s imperative we win.“The manager stressed after the game on Wednesday that we need to seriously get our heads on for today because it is a huge game.”If Dundee are to get a much-needed victory at Fir Park today, O’Dea has called on his team-mates to stick to the gameplan laid down by manager Jim McIntyrethey are to stand up to a test he expects to be “physically demanding”.“Football is  minutes and it’s about resilience and character. If you work all week on a gameplan, it’s about sticking to the gameplan and trusting it,” he added.“We’ll have a plan, we’ll be ready.“In fairness to the team, we’ve taken a lot of hits in the last three games but application hasn’t been lacking.“That isn’t much of a positive because it should be a bare minimum but we’re going to give everything as a squad because Motherwell are a team that are scrapping, too.“I’ve played against Motherwell a lot, I know them well and know their manager.“They are a very tough team who are well-organised and have quality.“They did very well last year, they’ve had a sticky start this time but that can happen after a good season.“It’s going to be very hard, physically demanding and you need to match that but also have the quality and calmness to play.“We will need every member of the squad, every tool we have to bring it out because we’ve had a horric start. But we have a huge chance over the next couple of weeks to get ourselves into a more comfortable position.”

title: landlord set to begin legal pursuit of dundee car salesman accused of reneging on leases
story: A landlord is set to begin his legal pursuit of a car salesman who is accused of reneging on lease agreements worth several thousand pounds.Jim Boyle, who together with his we Irene manages a large number of properties across the city, has instructed his lawyers to take action against Charles Sandeman.Mr Boyle had leased several dealerships to Mr Sandeman, including South Road Motors and Ancrum Autos, both of which are now closed.He claims Mr Sandeman has ceased payments on both, despite the leases running until .Mr Sandeman has previously claimed he had “get out” clauses written into the deals that would allow him to exit – a claim shot down by Mr Boyle, who sent copies of the leases to the Tele.Mr Boyle told the Tele he was “extremely disappointed” at Mr Sandeman’s alleged conduct.He said: “The option I am pursuing is to pursue Mr Sandeman until a resolution is reached, outstanding rent is recovered and new tenants are found.“The leases are still Charlie’s and will remain so until new tenants either take over the existing leases or new ones are started. It’s there in black and white – my lawyer in Edinburgh has said there are no get out clauses.“I’m very confident I will be able to resolve this matter in court and that I will be fully compensated.”Mr Sandeman previously told the Tele he did not consider himself liable for the leases.He declined to comment further when approached by the Tele this week.Mr Boyle added: “I haven’t heard from Mr Sandeman since he vacated the premises.“I’ve been in business for  years. I own a wide portfolio of properties in Dundee and nothing like this has ever happened. The clock is ticking for Mr Sandeman. The leases are still his responsibility.”

title: locals hope new coffee shop and pub plans could be a focal point
story: A new pub, cafe and shop could open in a village on the coastal route between Dundee and Angusplans are approved.An application for a cafe has been submitted to Angus Council by Arbroath architect AJ Fitchet on behalf of applicant, Kathy Powrie, who lives in the property next to the proposed site.Mrs Powrie and her business partner Lisa Turnbull hope to build a joint coffee shop, tearoom, licensed bar and retail space would be created in Inverkeilor, between Arbroath and Montrose.The site is on the corner of the A and Main Road.Lisa Tunbull said the plan was to build a wooden structure similar to the Lunan Farm Shop in neighbouring Lunan Bay, with a grocers selling local produce.“It started out as a plan for a shop and just grew from there,” she said. “We want to get the community and nearby farmers as involved as possible and sell fresh local produce from the shop.The application said it is hoped that the new facilities would become a “focal point” for the village, which has a population of about ,.The application has been supported by research claiming about % of the village’s population would use the cafe.The village was previously served by a shop and pub which closed a few years ago.Maria Watson, who has run Gordon’s restaurant in the village for  years, welcomed the plans.She said: “In the last few years we’ve lost a shop, a pub and a community place for people to go, so we would encourage this.“We know Kathy – she’s lived here a long time and good on her, we support the application.“It would be a good thing for the village and it’s just off the main road, so it would be good for tourism too.”The proposed opening hours for the tearoom and shop would be .am-pm, Tuesday to Thursday, and .am-pm on Saturday and Sunday.The bar area would be open between pm-midnight on  Friday and pm-midnight at weekends.Council planners will consider the application and respond in due course.

title: mothers know breast more than 50 of dundee mums breastfeed their newborns
story: Breast really is best according to a majority of Dundee mums – more than half of whom now breastfeed their newborns.Figures from NHS Scotland show .% of mothers in the city breastfeed, either exclusively or in combination with formula milk, in the first weeks of parenthood.That represents an increase of .% compared with three years ago.More mums are keeping it up for longer too – .% of mothers were still breastfeeding between six-eight weeks after giving birth.Breastfeeding has long been advocated by medical experts as beneficial – although it can be dficult for some mothers.Carmel Lloyd, head of education at the Royal College of Midwives, said: “Evidence clearly shows that breastfeeding in line with World Health Organisation guidance brings optimum benefits for the health of both mother and baby.”Among the new mums choosing to breastfeed is Vikki Don, , whose gave birth to her second child Georgia  weeks ago.“I definitely think it improves the bond you have with your baby – and you don’t have to worry about heating up bottlesyou’re out in public,” she said.“Attitudes to breastfeeding in public are changing too and, from talking to the support workers in the NHS, it seems more new mums are giving it a bash.”However, Vikki, from the West End, knows from personal experience that breastfeeding isn’t always possible. Her first-born Layla, now , had to be fed with a combination of breast and formula milk.She added: “It’s not always easy to breastfeed – and choosing not to does not make you a bad mum. It’s each to their own.”Janet Dalzell, infant nutrition co-ordinator at NHS Tayside, said new mums have access to support whatever their feeding choice.She said: “Breastfeeding takes time to learn for both the mum and baby so additional support is offered in hospital, in the community, at weekly groups and through social media groups.”

title: winter dog walk and fair to be held in dundee park

Entry is £.
