to answer about the source of money for Leave.EU." title"Arron Banks on the Andrew Marr Show " width"" ""  " title"Arron Banks on the Andrew Marr Show " width"" ""  Arron Banks on the Andrew Marr Show November   Comments‘Discrepancy’ in account of Leave campaign funding, says senior MPBelfastThe TV grilling of Brexit backer Arron Banks has exposed a “discrepancy” in his account of how he sourced £ million of funding to the Leave campaign, a senior MP has said.https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk discrepancy-in-account-of-leave-campaign-funding-says-senior-mp-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news uk article.ece bd AUTOCROP h bpanews_cdfc-d---eca_EmailThe TV grilling of Brexit backer Arron Banks has exposed a “discrepancy” in his account of how he sourced £ million of funding to the Leave campaign, a senior MP has said..pushMr Banks has insisted there was “no Russian money and no interference” after a criminal probe was launched into the source of the money.The businessman and co-founder of the Leave.EU campaign told BBC One’s Andrew Marr Show that all the cash came from a UK-registered company, and repeated claims that he was being targeted by Remain-supporting politicians.But Damian Collins, chairman of the House of Commons Culture, Media and Sport Committee, said Mr Banks had previously given evidence that the company existed to provide services to his other enterprises, and generated no cash of its own.A National Crime Agencyprobe has been launched into “suspected criminal offences” after the Electoral Commission said it had reasonable grounds to suspect that Mr Banks was not the true source of the cash.The elections watchdog also said that loans involved a company – Rock Holdings – based on the Isle of Man, which was impermissible under finance rules.The question is where did the money come from Damian Collins MPFacebookTwitterMr Collins told BBC Radio ’s Today programme that Mr Banks’ TV appearance had gone “not very far” in establishing the facts.“Basically Arron Banks said the money came from a holding company that he told the Select Committee provides services to the other companies he owns,” said the Conservative MP.“What’s not clear is where the money came from to get to that holding company in the first place, because this is a business that in and of itself doesn’t generate cash. The question is where did the money come from “It is a discrepancy because what he told us was that Rock Services really just provides services to other companies that he owns – provides cash, makes payments. It doesn’t make any money itself. It’s not selling products and services and generating cash.“For Rock Services to have money to give to Leave.EU or anyone , that money has got to have been put in that bank account by another company or another inidual.“If Rock Services made the donation, where did the money come from for Rock Services to do that  That is still not clear. No matter how many times he was asked that question, he didn’t answer it.”" width"" "" rel"nofollow"  Damian Collins chairs the Commons Culture Committee, which has been conducting an inquiry into fake news Mr Collins rejected suggestions that the UK’s departure from the European Union should be put on hold while the investigation into Mr Banks and Leave.EU is carried out.Questions over the validity of the referendum result could be raised onlymisconduct was “proven to be true as a consequence of the investigation”, he said.The “unprecedented” involvement of the NCA in the case was an important step because the agency was able to examine all financial records of Mr Banks’s businesses, including in areas outside UK jurisdiction such as the Isle of Man, said Mr Collins.“I want this to be done as quickly as possible,” he said. “But this isn’t a question of what should be done about the referendum. Ultimately that is a matter for Parliament.“It’s important that the investigation goes ahead as quickly as possible and that Arron Banks is investigated. There’s an argument he uses which is to say this is all politically motivated, this is not a proper investigation, it’s about trying to delay Brexit.“There are two issues here. There is the Brexit process which is ongoing and there is what should be a full and proper investigation into Mr Banks and the source of his funds.”The Electoral Commission’s review of referendum finances focused on £ million reported to have been loaned to Better For The Country by Mr Banks and his insurance companies and a £ million donation which he made alone.Mr Banks and Leave.EU chief executive Liz Bilney deny any wrongdoing.

Ireland AwardsSearchGoHome# News# UKFour in  Britons back second referendum offering in-out Brexit choice – pollA survey of , people was carried out before a live television debate on Channel  on Monday night." title"A poll suggests more than four in  Britons would back a vote on the terms of the Brexit deal negotiated by Theresa May " width"" ""  " title"A poll suggests more than four in  Britons would back a vote on the terms of the Brexit deal negotiated by Theresa May " width"" ""  A poll suggests more than four in  Britons would back a vote on the terms of the Brexit deal negotiated by Theresa May November   CommentsFour in  Britons back second referendum offering in-out Brexit choice – pollBelfastMore than four in  Britons would support holding a second Brexit referendum offering a choice between an agreed withdrawal deal or remaining in the EU, according to one of the largest polls conducted on the subject.https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk four-in--britons-back-second-referendum-offering-inout-brexit-choice-poll-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news uk article.ece e AUTOCROP h bpanews_daab-ee-f-ca-cedcde_EmailMore than four in  Britons would support holding a second Brexit referendum offering a choice between an agreed withdrawal deal or remaining in the EU, according to one of the largest polls conducted on the subject..pushSome , people were questioned by Channel  ahead of a live televised debate that will see senior politicians who supported both Leave and remain in  go head to head about the UK’s decision to quit the EU.Justice Minister David Gauke, shadow international trade secretary Barry Gardiner, Green MP Caroline Lucas and former Ukip leader Nigel Farage will take part in Brexit: What The Nation Really Thinks, which will be broadcast on Monday night.   The programme will reveal the headline findings from the survey carried out by Survation. Ahead of the broadcast the channel released a snapshot of data before the programme aired which revealed that views on a second referendum depended on the choice on offer.Some % said they would support a second referendum that was a binary choice between a deal and staying in, with % opposing a vote on those terms.However while it was backed by % of people who voted Remain, it was backed by just % of Leave voters.A referendum that offered a choice between a Theresa May deal or a no-deal Brexit was supported by % of respondents but opposed by %, with % “don’t knows”.And a third choice, between accepting the deal or reopening talks with a view to getting a better deal was supported by %, and opposed by %.– Brexit: What The Nation Really Thinks will be broadcast at pm on Monday.

title: former derry shirt factory worker calls sculpture funding donated charity
story: A Derry woman who worked in the city’s shirt factories for almost  years says has said that money being spent on a new sculpture should instead be given to children’s charity.It comes after the Derry News reported on October  that the original sculpture by Cork artist Louise Walsh had been scrapped due to spiralling costs.Over the last  years £, of government money had been spent on the project, and it was estimated that it would cost a further £, to complete and install Ms Walsh’s art work.However, Derry City and Strabane District Council’s Business and Culture Committee unanimously agreed last month to put a new process in place, whereby council officers will work with the Department of Communitiesto put a new £, project out for tender.But a Derry woman, who is aged  and worked in the shirt factories for  years, said she does not want the sculpture and suggested the money should donated to charity.“The sculpture to me is just ridiculous,” the woman, who did not wish to be named, told the Derry News.“The majority of people don’t want a big lump of iron. What use is that to anybody “It has already cost thousands upon thousands and it is lying in a scrap yard and now they are looking to buy another one.“The majority of people I worked with in Tillie and Henderson’s and Ben Sherman’s are dead and gone. This would mean nothing to them.”The woman saidthe money was given to a children’s charity it would be a much more fitting tribute to those who worked in the city’s shirt industry.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh“There are wains out there that needs medicine and clean water,” she continued.“That would mean something to the factory girls.”DebtShe said the factory workers had a long tradition of giving to charity, despite their low wages.“It was a hard time back then, but people were very resilient, but everyone was in debt and everyone was looking for money.“We worked very hard but we didn’t have much money because we were paid buttons, but on a Friday everyone put money in the boxes for St Anthony and St Theresa and to have masses said for people.“People had nothing but they still gave.“The majority of people I worked with would think that money should be spent for the living not for the dead.“I lie awake at night and think about this.”

title: watch elvis dracula santa entertain customers poundland store derry
story: Derry shoppers who have been spooked by Dracula in a city centre store over the Halloween period will be glad to hear that Santa Claus will be replacing him in the run-up to Christmas.The move is part of an ongoing gimmick being used to entertain customers at the self-service checkouts at the Poundland store in Waterloo Place, where shoppers have been receiving automated assistance from a number of unexpected voices.Last month the store introduced the first of its famous recruits when the instantly recognisable voice of Elvis caught self-scan checkout customers off guard with phrases like, ‘Unexpected item in bagging area, hound dog and ‘Thank you, thank you very much’.The latest checkout voice has been that of blood-sucking vampire, Dracula, who has been spooking shoppers at many customers, with one customer, Karen Downey, said it was a great idea to change the voice to suit the season, adding that Dracula was the right man for the job at this time of year considering
